numicius: <entryFree id="n31420" type="main" key="Nu^mi_ci^us1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nŭmīcĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nŭmīcus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n31420.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small river in Latium, near Lavinium, on the banks of which stood the grove of</hi> Juppiter Indiges, now <hi rend="ital">Rio Torto</hi>. </sense><sense id="n31420.1" n="A" level="2"> Form Numicius (rare): <cit><quote lang="la">amnis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 5, 9, § 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">corniger,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:3:647" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 3, 647</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31420.2" n="B" level="2"> Form Numicus: <cit><quote lang="la">venerandi Numici Unda,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:2:5:43" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 2, 5, 43</bibl></cit>; in <case>nom.</case> Numicus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:8:180" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 8, 180</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 2, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:2:15" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 2, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Orig. Gent. Rom. 14:2" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Orig. Gent. Rom. 14, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:150" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 150</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> Verg. A. 4, 620 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n31421" type="main" key="Nu^mi_ci^us2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nŭmīcĭus</orth>, <itype>a</itype>, <sense id="n31421.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of a Roman</hi> gens. So, L. Numicius Circeiensis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">T. Numicius Priscus,</quote> <trans><tr>a consul</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 63</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ti. Numicius,</quote> <trans><tr>a tribune of the people</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:30:109" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 30, 109</bibl></cit>: Minucius Thermus. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:16:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 16, 20</bibl>. To Numicius is addressed <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 6</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
numida: <entryFree id="n31422" type="main" key="Nu^mi^da"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nŭmĭda</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*noma/s</foreign>, <sense id="n31422.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a nomad</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Arabia Numidarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:8:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 8, 3, 8</bibl></cit> ( = Arabia Nomadum, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:72" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 16, 15, § 72</bibl>): Numidas dicimus quos Graeci <foreign lang="greek">*noma/das</foreign>, sive quod id genus hominum pecoribus negotietur, sive quod herbis, ut pecora aluntur, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=173" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 173</bibl> Müll.—</sense><sense id="n31422.1" n="II" level="1"> In partic., <hi rend="ital">a Numidian;</hi> usually in the <number>plur.</number>, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nŭmĭ-dae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <hi rend="ital">the Numidians, a people of Northern Africa, between Mauritania and the territory of Carthage</hi>, in the modern <cb n="NUMM" /> <hi rend="ital">Algiers</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 46:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 46, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:66:2" default="NO" valid="yes">66, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:89:7" default="NO" valid="yes">89, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:29:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 29, 31</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34" default="NO" valid="yes">34</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 41</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:11:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 11, 47</bibl>.— <cit><quote lang="la">Enslaved and used in Rome as mounted attendants and messengers,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 87:8" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 87, 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:123:6" default="NO">123, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 40</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 2877</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Numidarum columnae,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>of Numidian marble</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:7:182" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 7, 182</bibl></cit>.—In <hi rend="ital">gen. plur.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Numidūm gentes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:12:26:6" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 12, 26, 6</bibl></cit>.—In <number>sing.</number>: <cit><quote lang="la">Numida,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 12:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 12, 4</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31422.2" n="2" level="3"> As <hi rend="ital">adj., of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to the Numidians, Numidian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Numidae jaculatores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 28, 11</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">Numidae leones,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:2:183" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 2, 183</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">Numida dens,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>ivory</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:4:9:28" default="NO"><author>id.</author> P. 4, 9, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ursos figebat Numidas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:4:100" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 4, 100</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31422.3" n="3" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">A Roman surname</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Plotius Numida,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 36</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31422.4" n="B" level="2"> Hence, </sense><sense id="n31422.5" n="1" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nŭmĭdĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the country of Numidia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:1:6:1" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 1, 6, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 3, 2, § 22</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 8:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 8, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:13:2" default="NO" valid="yes">13, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:16:5" default="NO" valid="yes">16, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:3:12:6" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 3, 12, 6</bibl> et saep.— Whence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nŭmĭdĭānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj, Numidian</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 15, 16, § 55</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31422.6" n="2" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nŭmĭ-dĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., Numidian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">equi Numidici,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 30, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">scuta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 94:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 94, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cedri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:216" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 40, 79, § 216</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gallina,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:8:2:2" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 8, 2, 2</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">called also Numidicae aves,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:132" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 48, 67, § 132</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">marmor, called also Libycum, Poenum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 3, 2, § 22</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:49" default="NO" valid="yes">36, 6, 8, § 49</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 86:6" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 86, 6</bibl>: Numidicus, <hi rend="ital">a surname of</hi> Q. Caecilius Metellus, <hi rend="ital">bestowed on him for his victory over Jugurtha</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:11:2" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 11, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Vir. Ill. 62:1" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Vir. Ill. 62, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
numisius: <entryFree id="n31423" type="main" key="Nu^mi^si^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nŭmĭsĭus</orth>, <itype>a</itype>, <sense id="n31423.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of a Roman and Latin</hi> gens. </sense><sense id="n31423.1" n="1" level="3"> C. Numisius, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:41:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 41, 8</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31423.2" n="2" level="3"> T. Numisius Tarquiniensis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 45, 17</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31423.3" n="3" level="3"> Numisius <bibl default="NO"><author>Tiro</author>, Cic. Phil. 2, 4, 8</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n31423.4" n="4" level="3"> Numisius Lupus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 79</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 10</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n31423.5" n="5" level="3"> Numisius Rufus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 22</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">59</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">70</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n31423.6" n="6" level="3"> Numisius, <hi rend="ital">a Latin chieftain</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 11</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n31423.7" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nŭmĭsĭānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype> (<orth extent="full" lang="la">Nŭmĕsĭānus</orth>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 17, 5</bibl>), <hi rend="ital">adj., of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to a Numisius, Numisian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Numisiana vitis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:3:2:2" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 3, 2, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:7" default="NO">7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:12:43:9" default="NO">12, 43, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 2, 4, § 34</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
numisma: <entryFree id="n31424" type="main" key="nu^misma"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nŭmisma</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">nummisma</orth>, <itype>ătis</itype>, v. nomisma.</entryFree>
numistro: <entryFree id="n31425" type="main" key="Nu^mistro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nŭmistro</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n31425.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city in Lucania</hi>, near the mod. <hi rend="ital">Muro</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 27, 2, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:2:2:6" default="NO"><author>Front.</author> 2, 2, 6</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nŭmistrāni</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nŭ-mestrāni</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of</hi> Numistro, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:98" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 11, 15, § 98</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
numitor: <entryFree id="n31426" type="main" key="Nu^mi^tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nŭmĭtor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <sense id="n31426.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A king of Alba, brother of Amulius, father of Ilia, and grandfather of Romulus and Remus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:4:53" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 4, 53</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">809</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 75</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:773" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 14, 773</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:768" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 768</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:7:74" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 7, 74</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31426.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A Rutulian</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:342" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 342</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
numitorius: <entryFree id="n31427" type="main" key="Nu^mi^to_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nŭmĭtōrĭus</orth>, <itype>a</itype>, <sense id="n31427.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of a Roman</hi> gens. </sense><sense id="n31427.1" n="1" level="3"> C. Numitorious, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:63:section=163" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 63, § 163</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31427.2" n="2" level="3"> L. Numitorius, <hi rend="ital">a tribune of the people</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 58</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31427.3" n="3" level="3"> P. Numitorius, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 45</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:54" default="NO" valid="yes">54</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31427.4" n="4" level="3"> Q. Numitorius Pullus, <hi rend="ital">a leader of Fragellæ in the contest of that city with the Romans</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:34:105" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Inv. 2, 34, 105</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:22:62" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 5, 22, 62</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">His daughter</hi> was named Numitoria, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:3:6:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 3, 6, 17</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nummarius: <entryFree id="n31428" type="main" key="numma_rius"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nummārius</orth> (so acc. to the better MSS., others <orth extent="full" lang="la">nūmārius</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>nummus</etym>, <sense id="n31428.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to money, money-</hi>. </sense><sense id="n31428.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">difficultas nummaria,</quote> <trans><tr>pecuniary difficulty</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:28:section=69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 28, § 69</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">difficultas rei nummariae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 4, 6</bibl></cit>, § <cit><quote lang="la">11: theca nummaria,</quote> <trans><tr>a money-box, coffer</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:4:7:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 4, 7, 2</bibl></cit>: arca, Nov. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 495, 25</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">res,</quote> <trans><tr>the coinage</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:20:86" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 20, 86</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lex Cornelia nummaria,</quote> <trans><tr>passed by Sylla against forgery</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:42:section=100" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 42, § 100</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">poena,</quote> <trans><tr>a fine</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:4:8:11" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 4, 8, 11</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul.</author> Sent. 5, 6, 9</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31428.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">bribed with money, venal, mercenary</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">judices,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:16:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 16, 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:28:75" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 28, 75</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">varia judicum genera: nummarii pauci, sed omnes irati,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 27, 75</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">judicium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:57:section=131" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 57, § 131</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">interpres pacis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:36:101" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 36, 101</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tribunal,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ben. 1:9:4" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ben. 1, 9, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
nummatio: <entryFree id="n31429" type="spur" key="numma_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nummātĭo</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">nūmāt-</orth>, MSS. reading, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:45:115" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 2, 45, 115</bibl>; where Halm and Madv. have nundinatione, B. and K. mutatione.</entryFree>
nummatus: <entryFree id="n31430" type="main" key="numma_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nummātus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">nūmāt-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>numus</etym>, <sense id="n31430.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">moneyed, furnished with money, rich</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">homo bene nummatus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:22:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 2, 22, 58</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bene nummatum decorat Suadela Venusque,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 6, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nummatior revertor,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 1, p. 105, 19</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
nummosexpalponides: <entryFree id="n31431" type="main" key="Nummosexpalpo_ni^des"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nummos-expalpōnĭdes</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>nummus-expalpor</etym>, <sense id="n31431.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a flatterer for money</hi>, a fictitious comic name, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:4:6:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 4, 6, 22</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nummosus: <entryFree id="n31432" type="gloss" key="nummo_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nummōsus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">nūm-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>nummus</etym>, <sense id="n31432.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">well furnished with money, wealthy, rich</hi> (for the usual nummatus), <pb n="1227" /> <cb n="NUMQ" /> hoc inclinamentum hujuscemodi verborum, ut vinosus, mulierosus, religiosus, nummosus, significat copiam quandam immodicam rei, super quā dicitur, Nigid. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:4:9:2" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 4, 9, 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nummulariolus: <entryFree id="n31433" type="hapax" key="nummu^la_ri^o^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nummŭlārĭŏlus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">nūm-</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>nummularius</etym>, <sense id="n31433.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a money-changer</hi>, Sen. Apocol. <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></sense></entryFree>
nummularius: <entryFree id="n31434" type="main" key="nummu^la_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nummŭlārĭus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">nūm-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>nummulus</etym>, <sense id="n31434.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to moneychanging;</hi> as <pos>adj.</pos> very rare: <cit><quote lang="la">mensa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:14:3:20" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 14, 3, 20</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31434.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">nummŭlārĭus (nūm-</orth>), <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a money-changer, moneybroker</hi>, mensarius (post-Aug.; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">argentarius): nummulario, non ex fide versanti pecunias, manus amputavit mensaeque ejus affixit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=gal.:9" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Galb. 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 56</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:16:3:7" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 16, 3, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:12:57:8" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 12, 57, 8</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31434.2" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">An officer of the mint who tested the silver before it was coined</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 3226</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3227</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nummulus: <entryFree id="n31435" type="main" key="nummu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nummŭlus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">nūm-</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>nummus</etym>, <sense id="n31435.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">some money, money</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nummulis acceptis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:16:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 16, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nummulorum aliquid,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 19, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil aliud curant, nisi agros, nisi villulas, nisi nummulos suos,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 8, 13, 2</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
nummus: <entryFree id="n31436" type="main" key="nummus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nummus</orth> (thus written in the better MSS., others <orth extent="full" lang="la">nūmus</orth>), <itype>i</itype> (<sense id="n31436.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">gen. plur.</hi> usu. nummūm, but nummorum, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:2:115" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 1, 2, 115</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:49:section=117" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 49, § 117</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:3:149" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 3, 149</bibl>, etc.), <gen>m.</gen> <etym>from root <foreign lang="greek">ne/mw</foreign>; cf. numerus</etym>, <hi rend="ital">a piece of money, a coin, money</hi>. </sense><sense id="n31436.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">adulterini,</quote> <trans><tr>counterfeit money</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:23:91" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 23, 91</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adulterati,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul.</author> Sent. 5, 25, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aurei,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:12:8:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 12, 8, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plumbei,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:4:2:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 4, 2, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">argenteus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,011:2:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Reg. 2, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">putat suos nummos vos comedisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:1:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 6, 1, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">habere in nummis,</quote> <trans><tr>in ready money</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:8:10:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 8, 10, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:86:section=199" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 86, § 199</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">(hominem) non modo in aere alieno nullo, sed in suis nummis multis esse et semper fuisse,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 4, 6</bibl></cit>, § 11; <cit><quote lang="la">jactabatur enim temporibus illis nummus sic, ut nemo posset scire, quid haberet,</quote> <trans><tr>the value of money fluctuated</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:20:80" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 20, 80</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">asper,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>not worn smooth by use</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:3:69" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 3, 69</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 19:10" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 19, 10</bibl>: crescit amor nummi, Juv 14, 139.—</sense><sense id="n31436.2" n="II" level="1"> In partic. </sense><sense id="n31436.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A Roman silver coin, called also</hi> nummus sestertius, <hi rend="ital">and simply</hi> sestertius (v. sestertius), <hi rend="ital">a sesterce</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">eccos trīs nummos habes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:1:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 1, 4, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cogit Scandilium quinque illa milia nummum dare atque annumerare Apronio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:60:section=140" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 60, § 140</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 3, 61</bibl>, § <cit><quote lang="la">140: binis milibus nummum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 1, 1, § 8</bibl></cit>; cf. for the <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> nummūm, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:46:156" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 46, 156</bibl>, and v. Ritschl, prol. p. 89; <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> nummorum, <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 2, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:46" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 46 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=dom.:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Dom. 4 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:167" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 43, 68, § 167</bibl>—With <hi rend="ital">sestertius</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">percipere mille nongentos quinquaginta sestertios nummos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:3:3:9" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 3, 3, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sestertiis sescentis nummis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:3:3:9:section=13" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 3, 3, 9, § 13</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31436.4" n="2" level="3"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, like our <hi rend="ital">farthing, cent</hi>, to denote <hi rend="ital">a very small sum, a trifle, low price</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">assident, subducunt, ad nummum convenit,</quote> <trans><tr>to a farthing, to a cent</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:21:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 5, 21, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ecquis est ex tanto populo, qui bona C. Rabirii nummo sestertio sibi addici velit?</quote> <trans><tr>at a farthing's value</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,030:17:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rab. Post. 17, 45</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:17:55" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 17, 55</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae maxima inter vos habentur, divitiae, gratia, potentia, sestertio nummo aestimanda sunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 95:59" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 95, 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">damnatus ... et sestertio nummo veniit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:Epit. 55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> Epit. 55</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:1:2:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 1, 2, 34</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n31436.5" n="B" level="2"> As a Greek coin, <hi rend="ital">two</hi> drachmae (only in Plaut.): illi sunt drachumis miseri; <cit><quote lang="la">me nemo potest Minoris quisquam nummo, ut surgam, subigere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:3:2:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 3, 2, 19</bibl></cit>: <hi rend="ital">Me.</hi> Quibus hic pretiis porci veneunt sacres sinceri? <hi rend="ital">Cy.</hi> Nummo, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:2:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. 2, 2, 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:1:1:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 1, 1, 52</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:3:2:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Aul. 3, 2, 34</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
numnam: <entryFree id="n31437" type="main" key="numnam"><orth extent="full" lang="la">numnam</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">numne</orth>, v. num, I. <foreign lang="greek">z</foreign>.</entryFree>
numqua: <entryFree id="n31438" type="main" key="numqua"><orth extent="full" lang="la">numqua</orth>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:1:2:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 1, 2, 34</bibl>; more correctly written separate, num qua.</entryFree>
numquam: <entryFree id="n31439" type="main" key="numquam"><orth extent="full" lang="la">numquam</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">nunquam</orth> (both in good use; the former prevails before the Augustan age), <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>ne-umquam</etym>, <sense id="n31439.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">at no time, never</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">numquam edepol med istoc vinces,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:5:5:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 5, 5, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod (principium) si numquam oritur, ne occidit quidem umquam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:6:25:27" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 6, 25, 27</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:14:13:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 14, 13, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">videre mihi videor tantam dimicationem, quanta numquam fuit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 1, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">illum numquam, dum haec natio viveret sine curā futurum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:63:132" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sest. 63, 132</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">numquam ante hoc tempus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">numquam donec,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 34, 23</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31439.1" n="B" level="2"> Followed by a negative. </sense><sense id="n31439.2" n="1" level="3"> By a clause with <cb n="NUNC" /> <hi rend="ital">quin, ut non</hi>, to denote that which <hi rend="ital">always</hi> occurs: <cit><quote lang="la">numquam fui usquam, quin me omnes amarent plurimum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:9:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 5, 9, 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">numquam epistulam tuam accipio, ut non protinus una simus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 40:1" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 40, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31439.3" n="2" level="3"> With a negative in the same clause, affirmatively: <cit><quote lang="la">numquam non ineptum,</quote> <trans><tr>always</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:24:112" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 24, 112</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:12:18:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 12, 18, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 11:4" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 11, 4</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">probi mores numquam non plurimum profuerint,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7:2:33" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 7, 2, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">numquam nisi honorificentissime Pompeium appellat,</quote> <trans><tr>never otherwise than, always</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:6:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 6, 6, 10</bibl></cit>.—* </sense><sense id="n31439.4" n="II" level="1"> For non, <hi rend="ital">not, by no means</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui hodie numquam ad vesperam vivam!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:3:3:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 3, 3, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">numquam omnes hodie moriemur inulti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:670" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 670</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">numquam hodie effugies,</quote> <trans><tr>by no means</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:3:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> E. 3, 49</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:270" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 270</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:4:4:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 4, 4, 56</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:3:1:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 3, 1, 44</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil in mentem? numquam quidquam ( = prorsus nihil),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:1:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 4, 1, 12</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:1:1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 1, 1, 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
numquampostreddonides: <entryFree id="n31440" type="main" key="Numquampostreddo_ni^des"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Numquampostreddōnĭdes</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>numquam-post-reddo</etym>, <sense id="n31440.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">who never will return any thing</hi>, a comically formed name: <cit><quote lang="la">Quodsemelarripides Numquampostreddonides,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:4:6:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 4, 6, 22</bibl></cit> (dub.; al. Numquamposteaeripides, <hi rend="ital">from whom one can never recover any thing, Nevergetagain's son</hi>).</sense></entryFree>
numquando: <entryFree id="n31441" type="main" key="numquando"><orth extent="full" lang="la">numquando</orth>, <itype>more correctly written separate</itype>, num quando; v. num.</entryFree>
numquid: <entryFree id="n31442" type="main" key="numquid"><orth extent="full" lang="la">num-quid</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">nunqu-</orth>), <sense id="n31442.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adv. interrog</hi>. </sense><sense id="n31442.1" n="I" level="1"> In a direct interrogation, where there is no corresponding term in English: <cit><quote lang="la">numquid meministi?</quote> <trans><tr>do you remember?</tr></trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:5:4:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 5, 4, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">numquid, Gnatho, tu dubitas, quin ego perierim?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:8:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 5, 8, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">numquid Pomponius istis Audiret leviora, pater si viveret?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:4:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 4, 52</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 4, 136</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 2, 69</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">numquid ergo illuc accedo?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:3:79" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 6, 3, 79</bibl></cit>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">igitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7:1:55" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 7, 1, 55</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7:1:48" default="NO">7, 1, 48</bibl>.— Esp. in taking leave: num quid aliud? or num quid vis? <hi rend="ital">have you any thing further to say? do you want me longer? Eun.</hi> Quid? Me num quid vis? <hi rend="ital">Meg.</hi> Vale, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:1:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 2, 1, 53</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 2, 85</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:4:2:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Curc. 4, 2, 39</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:4:4:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Truc. 4, 4, 30</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">numquid aliut,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:2:1:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 2, 1, 57</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31442.2" n="II" level="1"> Rarely in an indirect interrog., <hi rend="ital">whether</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">scire sane velim, numquid necesse sit, comitiis esse Romae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:12:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 12, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si dubitare coeperit, numquid testatus decesserit, vel numquid vivat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:38:15:2" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 38, 15, 2</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
numquis: <entryFree id="n31443" type="main" key="numquis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">num-quis</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">nunqu-</orth>), <itype>qui, quae</itype> (qua), quod, <sense id="n31443.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pron. interrog. adj.</hi>, usually written separate, num quis; v. num.</sense></entryFree>
nunc: <entryFree id="n31444" type="main" key="nunc"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nunc</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>Sanscr. nu, nūnam, now; Gr. <foreign lang="greek">nu/, nu=n</foreign>; cf. Lat. num, with <hi rend="ital">demonstr.</hi> -ce</etym>, <sense id="n31444.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">now, at present, at this time</hi> (prop of that which is present to the speaker or writer). </sense><sense id="n31444.1" n="A" level="2"> In gen. </sense><sense id="n31444.2" n="1" level="3"> Contrasted with past time (opp. tum, tunc, antea, quondam, aliquando, olim, etc.): <cit><quote lang="la">longe aliam, inquam, praebes nunc atque olim,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:1:3:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 1, 3, 53</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 2, 1, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">alium esse censes nunc me atque olim,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:3:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> And. 3, 3, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnia, quae sunt conclusa nunc artibus, dispersa quondam fuerunt,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> de Or 1, 42, 187</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed tu illum animum nunc adhibe, quaeso, quo me tum esse oportere censebas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:1:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 6, 1, 16</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:1:2:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 1, 2, 24</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:776" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 776</bibl>: sed erat tunc excusatio oppressis; <cit><quote lang="la">nunc nulla est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:7:5:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 7, 5, 14</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:34:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 34, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:25:13" default="NO" valid="yes">4, 25, 13</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">arx minus aliquanto nunc munita quam antea,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,004:5:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Div. in Caecil. 5, 13</bibl></cit>: nunc si videtur, hoc; <cit><quote lang="la">illud alias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:11:23" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 11, 23</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:29:18:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 29, 18, 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:29" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 29</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aut nunc ... aut aliquando,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:25:67" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mil. 25, 67</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ante hoc tempus numquam ... sed nunc,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 1, 1, 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31444.3" n="2" level="3"> Contrasted with future time (opp. postea, mox, olim, etc.): <cit><quote lang="la">Cluentio nisi nunc satisfecero, postea satisfaciendi potestas non erit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:4:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 4, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:19:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 39, 19, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">deos nunc testes esse, mox fore ultores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 2, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:25:8" default="NO" valid="yes">3, 25, 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui olim nominabitur, nunc intellegitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:1:104" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 10, 1, 104</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:627" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 627</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:15:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 40, 15, 4</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31444.4" n="3" level="3"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg> of present time, without suggestion of contrast, = hodie, nostro tempore: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc tibi pater hic est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:5:4:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 5, 4, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Marcellus, qui nunc aedilis curulis est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:13:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 13, 57</bibl></cit>.— With the <hi rend="ital">interrog. ne</hi>, in the form <orth extent="full" lang="la">nun-cine</orth> (for num-ce-ne; <cit><quote lang="la">ante-class.): hem, nuncin demum?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:1:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 4, 1, 59</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n31444.5" n="B" level="2"> Strengthened by demum, denique, primum (v. h. vv.): <cit><quote lang="la">nunc demum intellego,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:6:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 2, 6, 62</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:3:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 2, 3, 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc demum rescribo his litteris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:16:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 16, 3, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tantum accessit, ut mihi nunc denique amare videar, antea dilexisse,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit> <cb n="NUNC" /> 14, 17, A, 5; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:14:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 9, 14, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:3:121" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 3, 121</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc, quam rem oratum huc veni, primum proloquar,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:prol. 50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. prol. 50</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 2, 63</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 2, 52</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc primum hoc aures tuae crimen accipiunt?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:8:section=24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 8, § 24</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 2, 60, § 147</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc quoque propter tuos ternos denarios nunc primum postulatur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 3, 25</bibl></cit>, § 63.—</sense><sense id="n31444.6" n="C" level="2"> In special phrases. </sense><sense id="n31444.7" n="1" level="3"> Ut nunc est, <hi rend="ital">as things now are, in the present state of affairs, as matters stand</hi>: constitui, ut nunc est, cum exercitu proficisci, Poll. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:31:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 31, 17</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae (causae) si manebunt ... et, ut nunc est, mansurae videntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:12:29:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 12, 29, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">suaviter, ut nunc est, inquam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:9:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 9, 5</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n31444.8" n="2" level="3"> Qui nunc sunt, <hi rend="ital">the men of this time, those now living, the present age</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">judiciis, qui nunc sunt. hominum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> ad Q. Fr. 1, 1, 15, § 43</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:22:147" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 22, 25, 71, § 147</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">tace stulta: non tu nunc hominum mores vides?</quote> <trans><tr>of the men of this day</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:3:1:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 3, 1, 57</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31444.9" n="3" level="3"> Nunc ipsum, <hi rend="ital">just now, at this very time</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quin nunc ipsum non dubitabo rem tantam abicere si id erit rectius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 3, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">8, 9, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">12, 40, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc tamen ipsum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 12, 16, 11</bibl></cit>.—Nunc repeated with emphasis: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc, nunc o liceat crudelem abrumpere vitam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:579" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 579</bibl></cit> (al. nunc o nunc); <cit><quote lang="la">5, 189: nunc, nunc adeste, nunc in hostiles domos Iram vertite,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:5:53" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 5, 53</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31444.10" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n31444.11" n="A" level="2"> Of past or future time, conceived as present, <hi rend="ital">now, at that time</hi>. </sense><sense id="n31444.12" n="1" level="3"> Of past time: <cit><quote lang="la">id adeo nos nunc factum invenimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:2:2:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 2, 2, 46</bibl></cit>: item Menandri Phasma nunc nuper dedit (Gr. <foreign lang="greek">nu=n a)/rti</foreign>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:prol. 9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. prol. 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc in causā refrixit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:23:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 23, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quos ego campos antea nitidissimos vidissem, hos ita vastatos nunc videbam, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:18:section=47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 18, § 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc reus erat apud Crassum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:24:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 2, 24, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum eum antea tui similem in dicendo viderim, tum vero nunc ... multo videbam similiorem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:71:250" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 71, 250</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">incerto nunc etiam exitu victoriae signa intulerunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:62:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 62, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">6, 40, 6</bibl>: nunc Saliaribus Ornare pul vinar deorum Tempus erat dapibus, Hor C. 1, 37, 2.—Esp. in orat. obliq., where the nunc of direct narration is retained: dixit, nunc demum se voti esse damnatum, Nep Timol. 5, 3; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:19:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 19, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:40:10" default="NO" valid="yes">3, 40, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:33:18" default="NO" valid="yes">8, 33, 18</bibl>; 8, 34, 3; <cit><quote lang="la">42, 52, 8: nec nunc adulteria objecturum ait,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:11:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 11, 30</bibl></cit>; cf. Nipperd. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:14:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 14, 35</bibl>; Krebs, Antibarb. p. 774. —</sense><sense id="n31444.13" n="2" level="3"> Of future time (rare): <cit><quote lang="la">quis nunc te adibit? Cui videberis bella? Quem nunc amabis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:8:16 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 8, 16 sq.</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:8:2:10" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 8, 2, 10</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31444.14" n="B" level="2"> Of the state of affairs, the condition of the argument, etc., <hi rend="ital">now, under these circumstances, in view of this</hi>. </sense><sense id="n31444.15" n="1" level="3"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc quoniam hominem generavit et ornavit deus, perspicuum sit, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:9:27" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 1, 9, 27</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4:9:73" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4, 9, 73</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">vera igitur illa sunt nunc omnia,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 33, 106</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non ego nunc vereor, ne sis mihi vilior istis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:1:2:25" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 1, 2, 25</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:1:333" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 1, 333</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc itaque et versus et cetera ludicra pono,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 1, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid nunc?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:3:3:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 3, 3, 71</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:3:77" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Aul. 2, 3, 77</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31444.16" n="2" level="3"> Introducing a fact or conclusion opposed to a previous supposition or thought: <cit><quote lang="la">etiamsi ad vos esset singulos aliquid ex hoc agro perventurum, tamen honestius eum vos universi quam singuli possideretis. Nunc vero cum ad nos nihil pertineat, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:31:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 2, 31, 85</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:1:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 3, 1, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:7:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 2, 7, 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,007:11:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Font. 11, 24</bibl>: si ecastor nunc habeas quod des, alia verba perhibeas; <cit><quote lang="la">nunc quia nihil habes, maledictis te eam ductare postulas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:1:3:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 1, 3, 36</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:3:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 3, 3, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:6:48" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 6, 48</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:5:7" default="NO">10, 5, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:40:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 40, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quodsi Mazaeus supervenisset, ingens clades accipi potuit: nunc, dum ille segnis in eo tumulo sedet, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:12:15" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 12, 15</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31444.17" n="C" level="2"> Nunc ... nunc, <hi rend="ital">now ... now; at one time, at another; sometimes ... sometimes</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tribuni plebis nunc fraudem, nunc neglegentiam consulum accusabant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc hac parte, nunc illā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 34, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut nunc in liminibus starent, nunc errabundi domos suas pervagarentur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 1, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc hos, nunc illos aditus omnemque pererrat Arte locum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:441" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 441</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">5, 189</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc huc, nunc illuc curro,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:10:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 10, 19</bibl></cit>.—Also thrice repeated: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc ad prima signa, nunc in medium, nunc in ultimo agmine aderat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:7:3:17" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 7, 3, 17</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:4:1:4" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 4, 1, 4</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">and even five times,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Dial. 5" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Dial. 5</bibl></cit> (Ira), 3, 6.—The first nunc is sometimes poetically omitted: pariterque sinistros, Nunc dextros solvere sinus, Verg. A. <pb n="1228" /> <cb n="NUNC" /> 5, 830.—</sense><sense id="n31444.18" n="b" level="4"> Nunc ... mox, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:63" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 63</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31444.19" n="c" level="4"> Nunc ... postremo, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 49</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31444.20" n="d" level="4"> Nunc ... modo, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 32</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:922" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 922</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31444.21" n="D" level="2"> In forming a climax, <hi rend="ital">but now</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:3:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 3, 3, 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae quidem multo plura evenirent, si ad quietem integri iremus: nunc onusti cibo et vino perturbata et confusa cernimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:29:60" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 29, 60</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si haec non ad cives Romanos, si non ad homines, verum ad bestias conqueri vellem, tamen tantā rerum atrocitate commoverentur. Nunc vero cum loquar apud senatores populi Romani, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:67:section=171" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 67, § 171</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si ... nunc (vero),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,007:11:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Font. 11, 25</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:7:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 2, 7, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:15:13:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 15, 13, 3</bibl>: cum aliquid videbatur caveri posse, tum id neglegi dolebam; <cit><quote lang="la">nunc vero, eversis omnibus rebus, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 21, 1</bibl></cit>: cum ... nunc vero, Brut. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:11:19:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 11, 19, 1</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31444.22" n="E" level="2"> In a transition, to introduce a new subject, <hi rend="ital">in that case, now, then</hi>: abi nunc, populi fidem implora, Auct. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:10:32:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 10, 32, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ben. 5:12:3 sq" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ben. 5, 12, 3 sq.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:6:35:5" default="NO">6, 35, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:1:3:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 1, 3, 17</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 14:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 14, 17</bibl>; for nunciam, v. jam, I. A. 1. b.</sense></entryFree>
nuncia: <entryFree id="n31445" type="main" key="nunci^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nuncĭa</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">nunt-</orth>), <itype>ae</itype>, v. nuntius.</entryFree>
nuncine: <entryFree id="n31446" type="main" key="nunci^ne^"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nuncĭnĕ</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">nuncc-</orth>), v. nunc, I. A. <sense id="n31446.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
nuncubi: <entryFree id="n31447" type="main" key="nuncu^bi_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nuncŭbī</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>from num with -cubi</etym>, <sense id="n31447.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">anywhere? whether anywhere?</hi> (ante-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">nuncubi hic vides citrum, aut aurum?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:2:4" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 2, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:2:5:2" default="NO">2, 5, 2</bibl>.—* </sense><sense id="n31447.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">at any time? ever?</hi> nuncubi meam Benignitatem sensisti in te claudier? <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:1:2:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 1, 2, 83</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nuncupatim: <entryFree id="n31448" type="main" key="nuncu^pa_tim"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nuncŭpātim</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>nuncupo</etym>, <sense id="n31448.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">by name</hi> (post-class.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 9, 16</bibl> <hi rend="ital">in carm.;</hi> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud. Mam.</author> Stat. Anim. 2, 9 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></sense></entryFree>
nuncupatio: <entryFree id="n31449" type="main" key="nuncu^pa_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nuncŭpātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n31449.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a naming, calling; a name, appellation</hi> (post-Aug.). </sense><sense id="n31449.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">justitiam universae virtutis nuncupatione complectitur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Dogm. Plat. 2, p. 15, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">regum, id. de Mundo, p. 68, 24: nuncupatio Augusta,</quote> <trans><tr>the title of Augustus</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 23, 6, 2</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31449.2" n="II" level="1"> In partic. </sense><sense id="n31449.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A naming</hi> or <hi rend="ital">appointing as heir</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum a parentibus inter liberos palam heres nuncuparetur, derisores vocabat, quod post nuncupationem vivere perseverarent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:38" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 38</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1251,001:Inst. 2" default="NO"><author>Gai.</author> Inst. 2</bibl>, §§ 104, 109; Ulp. Reg. t. 20, § 9; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:28:6:18" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 28, 6, 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:28:16:20" default="NO">28, 16, 20</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n31449.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A dedication</hi> of a book: mihi patrocinia ademi nuncupatione, Plin. H. N. praef. § 8.—</sense><sense id="n31449.5" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A public pronouncing</hi> of vows: <cit><quote lang="la">votorum nuncupationes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:16:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 16, 22</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:46" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 46</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sollennium verborum,</quote> <trans><tr>at the consecration of a temple</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:5:10" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 5, 10</bibl></cit>, n. 1.</sense></entryFree>
nuncupativus: <entryFree id="n31450" type="main" key="nuncu^pa_ti_vus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nuncŭpātīvus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n31450.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">so-called, nominal</hi>, Ambros. de Fide, 5, 1, 22.—Hence, <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">nuncŭpātīvē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">nominally</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Hier.</author> in Psa. 26</bibl>; Facund. Def 1, 4.</sense></entryFree>
nuncupator: <entryFree id="n31451" type="main" key="nuncu^pa_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nuncŭpātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n31451.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a namer</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">Pythagoras primus philosophiae nuncupator et conditor,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Flor. p. 352, 13</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
nuncupo: <entryFree id="n31452" type="main" key="nuncu^po"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nuncŭpo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype> (nuncupassit for nuncupaverit; <sense id="n31452.0" n="I" level="1"><xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">in the foll.</ref></xr>), <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>nomencapio</etym>, <hi rend="ital">to call by name, to call, name</hi> (mostly ante-class. and post-Aug.; <cit><quote lang="la">esp. in jurid. lang.: quem cultrix nomine nostro nuncupat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:1:246" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 1, 246</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:38:153" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 38, 153</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:3:27" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 3, 27</bibl> Spald. <hi rend="ital">N. cr.;</hi> cf.: designo, declaro, dico): nuncupare nominare valere apparet in legibus, ubi nuncupatae pecuniae sunt scriptae; <cit><quote lang="la">item in choro, in quo est: Aenea! Quis est qui meum nomen nuncupat? Item in Medio: Quis tu es mulier, quae me insueto nuncupāsti nomine?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 6:section=60" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 6, § 60</bibl></cit> Müll.: CVM NEXVM FACIET MANCIPIVMQVE VTI LINGVA NVNCVPASSIT ITA IVS ESTO, Fragm. XII. Tab. ap. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=173" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 173</bibl> Müll.; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:16:65" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 16, 65</bibl>; cf. also <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:57:245" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 57, 245</bibl>: nuncupata pecunia est nominata, certa (nomine certa?), nominibus propriis pronuntiata, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=173" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 173</bibl> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">tum illud, quod erat a deo donatum, nomine ipsius dei nuncupabant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:23:60" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 23, 60</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 28, 71</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">res utiles deorum vocabulis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 15, 38</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:91" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 12, 27, § 91</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Pompeii M. titulos omnes triumphosque hoc in loco nuncupari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:95" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 7, 26, 27, § 95</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquam reginam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:24:2:9" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 24, 2, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem Caesarem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Caes. 23:2" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Caes. 23, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Indigetem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:608" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 608</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>: alicujus fidem, <hi rend="ital">to invoke</hi>, Pac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 90, 11</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 78, v 141 Rib.).—</sense><sense id="n31452.1" n="II" level="1"> In partic. </sense><sense id="n31452.2" n="A" level="2"> Nuncupare heredem, <hi rend="ital">to name publicly before witnesses as one's heir</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">heredes palam, ita ut exaudiri possint nuncupandi sunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:28:1:21" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 28, 1, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">voce nuncupatus heres,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:12:15" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 12, 15 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:37:11:8" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 37, 11, 8</bibl>: nuncupatum<cb n="NUND" />  testamentum, <hi rend="ital">a testament drawn up in the presence of witnesses, in which the testator names his heirs</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:8:18:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 8, 18, 5</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n31452.3" n="B" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">to constitute</hi> or <hi rend="ital">appoint as one's heir</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:4" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:38" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Calig. 38</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec quia offendit alius, nuncuparis, sed quia ipse meruisti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:43" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 43</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31452.4" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To announce publicly, proclaim formally</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">consultatum pro rostris an in senatu an in castris adoptio nuncuparetur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 17</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n31452.5" n="D" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To pronounce vows publicly, to offer vows, to vow</hi>: vota nuncupata dicuntur, quae consules, praetores cum in provinciam proficiscuntur faciunt: ea in tabulas praesentibus multis referuntur. At Santra L. II. de verborum antiquitate satis multis nuncupata colligit non directo nominata significare, sed promissa et quasi testificata, circumscripta, recepta, quod etiam in votis nuncupandis esse convenientius, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=173" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 173</bibl> Müll.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:3:4:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 3, 4, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 63</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum consul more majorum secundum vota in Capitolio nuncupata, cum lictoribus paludatus profectus ab urbe esset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:41:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 41, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">solvere vota nuncupata pro incolumitate exercitus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:1:1" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 1, 1 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
nuncusque: <entryFree id="n31453" type="main" key="nuncusque"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nunc-usque</orth>, <sense id="n31453.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adv., until now</hi> (postclass.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 14, 2, 13 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
nundialis: <entryFree id="n31454" type="main" key="nundi^a_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nundĭālis</orth>, v. nundinalis.</entryFree>
nundina: <entryFree id="n31455" type="main" key="nundi^na1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nundĭna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, v. nundinus, II.</entryFree>
<entryFree id="n31456" type="main" key="Nundi^na2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nundĭna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, v. nundinus, I.</entryFree>
nundinae: <entryFree id="n31457" type="main" key="nundi^nae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nundĭnae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, v. nundinus, II.</entryFree>
nundinalis: <entryFree id="n31458" type="hapax" key="nundi^na_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nundĭnālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>nundinae</etym>, <sense id="n31458.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to the</hi> nundinae: <cit><quote lang="la">nundinalis cocus,</quote> <trans><tr>a bad cook, employed only on marketdays</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:4:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 2, 4, 45</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:3:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 3, 2, 6</bibl>, sqq. (or perhaps nundinalis stands for nundinarius, v. h. v., and nundinalis cocus is <hi rend="ital">a market-cook, one who sets up a movable kitchen for the people who come to market</hi>. Wagner prefers the reading nundialis, and explains the phrase, <hi rend="ital">a cook hired only for the</hi> silicernium, <hi rend="ital">fit only to prepare a funeral feast;</hi> cf. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=173" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 173</bibl> Müll.).</sense></entryFree>
nundinarius: <entryFree id="n31459" type="main" key="nundi^na_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nundĭnārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n31459.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to a market</hi> or <hi rend="ital">fair, market-</hi> (postAug.): <cit><quote lang="la">forum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:208" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 51, 77, § 208</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oppidum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:80" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 12, 17, 40, § 80</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">epulae,</quote> <trans><tr>given to those who attended the market</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:17:2:69" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 17, 2, 69</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
nundinaticius: <entryFree id="n31460" type="main" key="nundi^na_ti_ci^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nundĭnātīcĭus</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">-tĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>nundinor</etym>, <sense id="n31460.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">for sale</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">capita,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>the unveiled faces of girls</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Virg. Vel. 3</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
nundinatio: <entryFree id="n31461" type="main" key="nundi^na_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nundĭnātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, lit., <sense id="n31461.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the holding of a market</hi> or <hi rend="ital">fair;</hi> hence, <hi rend="ital">a trading, trafficking, buying and selling</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">fuit nundinatio aliqua, et isti non nova, ne causam diceret,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Verr 2, 5, 5, § 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae libido in jure dicundo fuerit, quae varietas decretorum, quae nundinatio,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 1, 46</bibl></cit>, § <cit><quote lang="la">120: juris et fortunarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:1:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 1, 3, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:45:115" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 45, 115</bibl> Orell. <hi rend="ital">N. cr.</hi>—</sense><sense id="n31461.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The market-price</hi>, Cod. Th. 7, 4, 32.</sense></entryFree>
nundinator: <entryFree id="n31462" type="main" key="nundi^na_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nundĭnātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n31462.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a trader, trafficker</hi>. </sense><sense id="n31462.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, Paul. ex Fest. s. v. nundinae, p. 173 Müll.: NVNDINATOR, <hi rend="ital">an appellation of Mercury as the patron deity of brokers</hi>, Inscr. Rein. cl. 1, n. 80.—</sense><sense id="n31462.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: nundinator salutis publicae, Ps.-<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:Decl. 12:3" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> Decl. 12, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nundino: <entryFree id="n31463" type="main" key="nundi^no"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nundĭno</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, v. nundinor <sense id="n31463.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
nundinor: <entryFree id="n31464" type="main" key="nundi^nor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nundĭnor</orth>, <itype>ātus, 1</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos> <etym>nundinae</etym>. <sense id="n31464.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to attend</hi> or <hi rend="ital">hold market, to trade, traffic</hi> (syn. mercor): <cit><quote lang="la">in captivorum pretiis, nec victoris animo, nec magni ducis more nundinans,</quote> <trans><tr>chaffering</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nefandis nundinandi commerciis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 31, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 1, 16</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31464.1" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to come together in large numbers</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in Solonio, ubi ad focum angues nundinari solent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:31:66" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 31, 66</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31464.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to get by trafficking; to purchase, buy</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nundinari senatorium nomen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:49:section=122" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 49, § 122</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jus ab aliquo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 1, 46</bibl></cit>, § <cit><quote lang="la">119: totum imperium populi Romani,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:3:4:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 3, 4, 10</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31464.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To trade away, to sell</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">constabat eum in cognitionibus patriis nundinari praemiarique solitum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:7" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">judices sententias suas pretio nundinantur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 10, p. 255, 13</bibl></cit>. —<hi rend="ital">Act.</hi> collat. form <orth extent="full" lang="la">nundĭno</orth>, <hi rend="ital">to sell</hi> (postclass.): nundinatum pudorem, Firm. Math. 6, 31 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>; Auct. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Capitol.</author> Gord. 24 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; so in <hi rend="ital">part. perf.</hi>: nundinatus, <hi rend="ital">traded away, sold</hi>, Firm. Math. 6, 31 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi>; Prud. <foreign lang="greek">stef</foreign>. 10, 969; <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Virg. Vel. 13</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nundinum: <entryFree id="n31465" type="main" key="nundi^num"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nundĭnum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, v. nundinus, III.</entryFree>
nundinus: <entryFree id="n31466" type="main" key="nundi^nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nundĭnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>novem-dies</etym>, <sense id="n31466.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to nine days;</hi> hence, <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi> <cb n="NUNT" /> </sense><sense id="n31466.1" n="I" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nundĭna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> (sc. dea), <hi rend="ital">the goddess who presided over the purification and naming of infants, which took place in the case of boys on the ninth and in that of girls on the eighth day after birth</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 1, 16, 36</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31466.2" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">nundĭnae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype> (<number>sing.</number> collat. form <orth extent="full" lang="la">nundĭna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 7, 5</bibl>), <gen>f.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the ninth day</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">the market-day, the weekly market;</hi> denoting the time, the place, and the business (on market-days the country people came into the city for the purpose of buying and selling, and of attending to public and religious affairs): nundinas feriatum diem esse voluerunt antiqui, ut rustici convenirent mercandi vendendique causā: eumque nefastum, ne, si liceret cum populo agi, interpellarentur nundinatores, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=173" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 173</bibl> Müll.; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">Rutilius scribit, Romanos instituisse nundinas, ut octo quidem diebus in agris rustici opus facerent, nono autem die, intermisso rure, ad mercatum Legesque accipiendas Romam venirent,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 1, 16, § 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">annum ita diviserunt, ut nonis modo diebus urbanas res usurparent, reliquis VII. ut rura colerent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2 praef" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2 praef.</bibl></cit> § 1: erat in eo ipso loco nundinarum <foreign lang="greek">panh/guris</foreign>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:14:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 14, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">illi Capuam nundinas rusticorum, horreum Campani agri esse voluerunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:33:89" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 2, 33, 89</bibl></cit>;
