A. 3, 579</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pascere ac nutrire furorem (al. favorem),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:7:497" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 7, 497</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">impetus ille sacer qui vatum pectora nutrit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:4:2:25" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 4, 2, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">carmen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:3:4:26" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 4, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">artes bonas, praecipue studia litterarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Epit. 41:14" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Epit. 41, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nummi, quos hic quincunce modesto nutrieras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:5:149" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 5, 149</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Graeciam,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>to treat mildly</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:36:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 36, 35</bibl></cit>.—Of fire, <hi rend="ital">to feed</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">gnes suscitat foliisque nutrit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:643" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 643</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">6, 493</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">graves simultates, quas Mucianus callide nutriebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 53 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nimiam ac marcentem diu pacem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 36</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
nutrior: <entryFree id="n31513" type="main" key="nu_tri^or"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nūtrĭor</orth>, <itype>īri</itype>, = nutrio, v. nutrio.</entryFree>
nutritius: <entryFree id="n31514" type="main" key="nu_tri_ti^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nūtrītĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. nutricius.</entryFree>
nutritor: <entryFree id="n31515" type="main" key="nu_tri_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nūtrītor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>nutrio</etym>, <sense id="n31515.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a bringer up, rearer, breeder</hi> (post-Aug.): <cit><quote lang="la">volucrum equorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:10:228" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 10, 228</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Alexandri Severi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Lampr.</author> Alex. Sev. 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a nutritore suo manumissus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,004:7" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Gram. 7</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 2816</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nutritorius: <entryFree id="n31516" type="main" key="nu_tri_to_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nūtrītōrĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>nutritor</etym>. <sense id="n31516.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Nourishing, nutritive</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">lac omne nutritorium est,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Theod. Prisc.</author> de Diaet. 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31516.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to bringing up, rearing</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cunae nutritoriae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Conf. 12:27" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Conf. 12, 27</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
nutritura: <entryFree id="n31517" type="main" key="nu_tri_tu_ra"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nūtrītūra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>nutrio</etym>, = nutricatus, <sense id="n31517.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a nursing, suckling</hi>, Cassiod.</sense></entryFree>
nutritus: <entryFree id="n31518" type="main" key="nu_tri_tus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nūtrītus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood>, from nutrio.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n31519" type="spur" key="nu_tri_tus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nūtrītus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, a false read. for intrita, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:22:114" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 22, 24, 53, § 114</bibl>; v. Sillig ad h. l.</entryFree>
nutrix: <entryFree id="n31520" type="main" key="nu_trix"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nūtrix</orth> (old orthogr. <orth extent="full" lang="la">notrix</orth>, acc. to <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:4:16" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 4, 16</bibl>), <itype>īcis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>nutrio</etym>, <sense id="n31520.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a wet-nurse, nurse</hi>. </sense><sense id="n31520.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnia minima mansa, ut nutrices infantibus pueris, in os inserant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:39:162" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 39, 162</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum lacte nutricis errorem suxisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:1:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 3, 1, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sidera nutricem nutricis fertile cornu Fecit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:5:127" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 5, 127</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:632" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 632</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 645</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Jubae tellus leonum Arida nutrix,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:22:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 22, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gallina nutrix,</quote> <trans><tr>a hen that has chickens</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:8:11:13" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 8, 11, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nutricis tolerare labores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:6:593" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 6, 593</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mater nutrix,</quote> <trans><tr>a mother that suckles her own infant</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:12:1:5" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 12, 1, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Fabr.</author> p. 188</bibl>, n. 428: <cit><quote lang="la">est enim illa (oratio) quasi nutrix ejus oratoris, quem informare volumus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:11:37" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 11, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nutricis pallium (prov. of any thing soiled, dirty),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:3:3:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 3, 3, 30</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31520.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n31520.3" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">She who nourishes</hi> or <hi rend="ital">maintains</hi> a thing: <cit><quote lang="la">virgines perpetui nutrices et conservatrices ignis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 4, 151</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n31520.4" n="2" level="3"> Nutrices, <hi rend="ital">the breasts</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:64:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 64, 18</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31520.5" n="3" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">A piece of ground in which shoots of trees are planted in order to be set out again, a nursery garden</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 10, 12, § 66</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31520.6" n="4" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">The land that supports a family</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:4:111" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 4, 111</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31520.7" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a nurse</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nostramne, ere, vis nutricem, quae nos educat, Abalienare a nobis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:4:111" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 4, 111</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">curarum maxima nutrix Nox,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:81" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 81</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Sicilia nutrix plebis Romanae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:2:section=5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 2, § 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nutrix Discordia belli,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> in Ruf. 1, 30</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
nutus: <entryFree id="n31521" type="main" key="nu_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nūtus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>nuo, ĕre (of abnuo, etc.); cf. nuto</etym>, <sense id="n31521.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a nodding, a nod</hi>. </sense><sense id="n31521.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">Scipio nutu finire disceptationem potuisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 34, 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nutu tremefecit Olympum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:106" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 106</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">digitisque saepe est nutuque locutus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:2:453" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 2, 453</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">signaque dat nutu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:1:418" default="NO"><author>id.</author> F. 1, 418</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nutus conferre loquaces,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:2:21" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 2, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">digiti,</quote> <trans>i.e. <tr>a beckoning</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Herm. 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">membrorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:188" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 30, 35, § 188</bibl></cit>: uno meo <pb n="1231" /> <cb n="NYCT" /> nutu jugulari utrumque vestrum posse, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:32" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 32</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nutibus oculorum,</quote> <trans><tr>winks</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,048:3:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Isa. 3, 16</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31521.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a downward tendency</hi> or <hi rend="ital">motion, gravity</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">terrena suopte nutu et suo pondere in terram ferri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:17:40" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 17, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">terra suā vi nutuque tenetur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:45:178" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 3, 45, 178</bibl></cit>; so in <number>plur.</number>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:39:98" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 39, 98</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31521.3" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">command, will, pleasure</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad eorum arbitrium et nutum totos se fingunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:8:24" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 8, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jura omnia praetoris nutu atque arbitrio meretriculae gubernari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:13:section=34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 13, § 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad alicujus voluntatem nutumque convertere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:10:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 3, 10, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnia deorum nutu atque potestate administrari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:3:9:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 3, 9, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">auctoritate nutuque iegum domitas habere libidines,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:43:194" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 43, 194</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">paratum esse ad nutum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:7:6:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 7, 6, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad nutum praesto esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:31:section=78" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 31, § 78</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">respirare contra nutum dicionemque alicujus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Quint. 30, 94</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alterius sub nutu degitur aetas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:1122" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 1122</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">saevae nutu Junonis eunt res,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:592" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 592</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
nux: <entryFree id="n31522" type="main" key="nux"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nux</orth>, <itype>nŭcis</itype> (<sense id="n31522.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">gen. plur.</hi> nucerum for nucum, Cael. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 40</bibl> P.), <gen>f.</gen> <etym>etym. dub.</etym>, <hi rend="ital">a nut</hi>. At weddings it was customary to strew nuts on the floor: <cit><quote lang="la">sparge, marite, nuces,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:8:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 8, 30</bibl></cit>; cf. Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad E. 8, 30</bibl>; Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=173" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 173</bibl> Müll.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:86" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 22, 24, § 86</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:5:135" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 5, 135</bibl>. Nutshells were used in coloring the hair: <cit><quote lang="la">viridi cortice tincta nucis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:8:44" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 8, 44</bibl></cit>. Nuts were strewn at the festival of Ceres, Sinn. Capito ap. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=177" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 177</bibl> Müll. Children played with nuts, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:83" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 83</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:61:131" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 61, 131</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">hence, prov.: nuces relinquere,</quote> <trans><tr>to give up childish sports, to betake one's self to the serious business of life, to throw away our rattles</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:1:10" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 1, 10</bibl></cit>: nux cassa, <hi rend="ital">a nutshell</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tene amatorem esse inventum inanem quasi cassam nucem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:3:137" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 1, 3, 137</bibl></cit>.—Fig. of a thing of no value, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:5:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 5, 36</bibl> ( = res vel vilissima); cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">non ego tuam empsim vitam vitiosā nuce,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:3:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 2, 3, 45</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31522.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n31522.2" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A fruit with a hard shell</hi> or <hi rend="ital">rind</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nux amara,</quote> <trans><tr>a bitter almond</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:3:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 3, 10</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:7:13" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 7, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 7, 7, § 26</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">castaneae nuces,</quote> <trans><tr>chestnuts</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:2:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 2, 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nux pinea,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 2, 6, 1</bibl></cit>; <hi rend="ital">the fruit of the</hi> tithymalus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:26:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 26, 8, 40, § 66</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31522.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A nut-tree</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">inter primas germinant ulmus, salix, nuces,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:97" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 25, 41, § 97</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 24, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:11:119" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 11, 119</bibl>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">an almond-tree</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:187" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 187</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nyctalmos: <entryFree id="n31523" type="main" key="nyctalmos"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nyctalmos</orth> = nyctalopia, q. v.</entryFree>
nyctalopa: <entryFree id="n31524" type="main" key="nycta^lo_pa"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nyctălōpa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>nyctalops</etym>, <sense id="n31524.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the disease of one who cannot see in the twilight, nyctalopy</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Marc. Emp.</author> 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nyctalopia: <entryFree id="n31525" type="greek" key="nycta^lo_pi^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nyctălōpĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">nuktalwpi/a</foreign>, <sense id="n31525.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the disease of one who cannot see in the twilight, nyctalopy</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 4, 8, 8</bibl> (al. nyctalmos).</sense></entryFree>
nyctalops: <entryFree id="n31526" type="greek" key="nycta^lops"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nyctălops</orth>, <itype>ōpis</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">nukta/lwy</foreign>. <sense id="n31526.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">That cannot see in the twilight</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:170" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 28, 11, 47, § 170</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:203" default="NO" valid="yes">8, 50, 76, § 203</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:21:1:10" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 21, 1, 10</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n31526.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">That sees only at night</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nyctalopas, qui per noctem vident et per diem obscuritatem patiuntur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Theod. Prisc.</author> 1, 10</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31526.2" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The plant</hi> nyctegretos, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 11, 36, § 62</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nyctegresia: <entryFree id="n31527" type="main" key="Nycte_gre^si^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nyctēgrĕsĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*nukthgresi/a</foreign> (<foreign lang="greek">*nuktegersia</foreign>), <sense id="n31527.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Night-watching</hi>, the title of a tragedy of Attius (v. Trag. Rel. Fragm. p. 168 Rib. sq.).</sense></entryFree>
nyctegretos: <entryFree id="n31528" type="greek" key="nycte_gre^tos"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nyctēgrĕtos</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">-on</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">nukth/greton</foreign>, <sense id="n31528.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plant that shines by night</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 11, 36, § 62</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nycteis: <entryFree id="n31529" type="main" key="Nycte_is"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nyctēis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, v. Nycteus.</entryFree>
nyctelius: <entryFree id="n31530" type="main" key="Nycte^li^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nyctĕlĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">*nukte/lios</foreign>, <sense id="n31530.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an epithet of Bacchus</hi>, because his mysteries were celebrated at night: <cit><quote lang="la">Nyctelius pater,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:1:567" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 1, 567</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">latex,</quote> <trans><tr>wine</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Oedip. 492" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Oedip. 492</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nyctelia sacra,</quote> <trans><tr>the Bacchanalia</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 4, 383</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
nycteris: <entryFree id="n31531" type="main" key="nycte^ris"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nyctĕris</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">nukteri/s</foreign>, <sense id="n31531.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plant</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Theod. Prisc.</author> 4, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nycteus: <entryFree id="n31532" type="main" key="Nycteus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nycteus</orth>, <itype>ĕi and ĕos</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*nukteu/s</foreign>, <sense id="n31532.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a son of Hyrieus and the nymph Clonia, and father of Antiopa</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nycteos Antiope,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:15" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3, 15</bibl></cit> (4, 14), 12.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n31532.1" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nyctēis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the Nycteide</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">Antiopa</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nycteida,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:6:111" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 6, 111</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nycteidos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:7:190" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 7, 190</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 7" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 7</bibl> and 155.</sense></entryFree>
nycticorax: <entryFree id="n31533" type="greek" key="nycti^co^rax"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nyctĭcŏrax</orth>, <itype>ăcis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">nuktiko/rac</foreign>, <sense id="n31533.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the night-raven</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Hier.</author> Ep. 106</bibl>, n. 86; <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 12, 7, 41</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul. Nol.</author> Ep. 40, 6</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nyctimene: <entryFree id="n31534" type="main" key="Nycti^me^ne_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nyctĭmĕnē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*nuktime/nh</foreign>, <sense id="n31534.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the daughter of Epopeus, king of Lesbos, who unknowingly<cb n="NYSA" />  had intercourse with her father: when she discovered it, she fled in despair to the woods, where she was changed by Minerva into a night-owl</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:591" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 591</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. G. 1, 403</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 204" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 204</bibl> and 253.</sense></entryFree>
nyctostrategus: <entryFree id="n31535" type="greek" key="nyctostra^te_gus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nyctostrătēgus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> = <foreign lang="greek">nuktostra/thgos</foreign>, <sense id="n31535.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the Greek name of the</hi> praefectus vigilum, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:50:4:18:section=12" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 50, 4, 18, § 12</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nyma: <entryFree id="n31536" type="main" key="nyma"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nyma</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n31536.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plant</hi>, otherwise unknown, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:106" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 27, 12, 82, § 106</bibl> (al. nigina).</sense></entryFree>
nympha: <entryFree id="n31537" type="greek" key="nympha"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nympha</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">nymphē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype> (<sense id="n31537.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">dat. plur.</hi> NYMPHABVS, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 1629</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">NYMFABVS,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 1630</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">NYMPHIS,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 1627</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1630</bibl> sq.), <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">nu/mfh</foreign>. </sense><sense id="n31537.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A bride, a mistress</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:1:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 1, 27</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:3:1:21" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 3, 1, 21</bibl> (al. merita).—</sense><sense id="n31537.2" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">A young woman</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">se quoque nympha tuis ornavit Iardanis armis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:9:103" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 9, 103</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31537.3" n="II" level="1"> Nymphae, <hi rend="ital">demi-goddesses, who inhabit the sea, rivers, fountains, woods, trees, and mountains; nymphs</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nymphae, genus amnibus unde est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 71</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">10, 551</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:5:540" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 5, 540</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nympha Maenalis,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>Carmenta, the mother of Evander</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:1:634" default="NO"><author>id.</author> F. 1, 634</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nymphae Libethrides,</quote> <trans><tr>the Muses</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:7:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 7, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vocalis Nymphe,</quote> <trans><tr>Echo</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:357" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 357</bibl></cit>. Vows were made to the fountain-nymphs in cases of sickness or of drought, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:17:43" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 17, 43</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 1631 sq.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n31537.4" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">water</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">et cadit in patulos Nympha Aniena lacus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:16" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3, 16</bibl></cit> (4, 15), 4.—</sense><sense id="n31537.5" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">A fountain</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:6:43:2" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 6, 43, 2</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31537.6" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The pupa</hi> or <hi rend="ital">nymph</hi> of an insect: <cit><quote lang="la">alius evolat, alius in nymphā est, alius in vermiculo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 21, 24, § 71</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:48" default="NO" valid="yes">11, 16, 16, § 48</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

Emp.</author> 33</bibl>), <sense id="n31538.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the water-lily</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:75" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 25, 7, 37, § 75</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 67</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

C. 3, 26, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:36:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 42, 36, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:144" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 22, 26, § 144</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:5:720" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 5, 720</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
<entryFree id="n31540" type="gloss" key="nymphaeum2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nymphaeum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, v. nympheum.</entryFree>

D. 3, 23, 58</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

lang="greek">*nu=sa</foreign>, <sense id="n31555.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of several cities</hi>. </sense><sense id="n31555.1" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A city in Caria, on the slope of Mount Messogis</hi>, the modern <cb n="O" /> <hi rend="ital">Nasli</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Sultan-hissar</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:108" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 29, 29, § 108</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n31555.2" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A city in Palestine</hi>, the modern <hi rend="ital">El Baisan</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 18, 16, § 74</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31555.3" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A city in India, on Mount Meros, the birthplace of Bacchus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:805" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 805</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:3:7" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 3, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 21, 23, § 79</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:8:10" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 8, 10</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:12:7:6" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 12, 7, 6</bibl>; cf.: celso Nysae de vertice.—</sense><sense id="n31555.4" n="II" level="1"> Hence, </sense><sense id="n31555.5" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ny-saeus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> </sense><sense id="n31555.6" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Nysa in Caria</hi>.—<orth extent="full" lang="la">Nysaei</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the Nysæans</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:64:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 13, 64, 1</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31555.7" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Nysa, in India;</hi> <usg type="style">poet.</usg> for <hi rend="ital">Bacchic</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">chori,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:15" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3, 15</bibl></cit> (4, 16), 22: <cit><quote lang="la">palmes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:7:198" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 7, 198</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Hydaspes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:8:227" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 8, 227</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cacumina Gauri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:12:160" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 12, 160</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31555.8" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nȳsēis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj. f., Nysæan</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">Bacchic</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nymphae Nyseides,</quote> <trans><tr>who reared Bacchus</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:3:769" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 3, 769</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31555.9" n="C" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nȳsēĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., Nysæan</hi>, i.e. <hi rend="ital">Bacchic</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">juga Nyseia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:8:801" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 8, 801</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31555.10" n="D" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nȳseus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">dissyl.</orth>), <itype>ĕi and ĕos</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">an epithet of Bacchus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 13</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31555.11" n="E" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nȳsĭ-ăcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., Nysæan</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">Bacchic</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 2, § 98</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31555.12" n="F" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nȳsĭas</orth>, <itype>ădis</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj. f., Nysæan</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nysiades Nymphae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:3:769" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 3, 769</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n31555.13" n="G" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nȳsĭgĕna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">born in Nysa</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum Nysigenis Silenis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:64:252" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 64, 252</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31555.14" n="H" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nȳsĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., Nysian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quam (hederam) quidam Nysiam, alii Bacchicam vocant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:147" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 34, 62, § 147</bibl></cit>; also, <hi rend="ital">an epithet of Bacchus</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nysius et Semeleius Liber,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 5, 176</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fl. 25, 60</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nysion: <entryFree id="n31556" type="main" key="ny_si^on"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nȳsĭon</orth>, <itype>ĭi</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n31556.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">ivy</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 98</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nyssos: <entryFree id="n31557" type="main" key="Nyssos"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nyssos</orth>, i., <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*nu/ssos</foreign>, <sense id="n31557.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city in Macedonia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 10, 17, § 36</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nysus: <entryFree id="n31558" type="main" key="Ny_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nȳsus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n31558.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the tutor of Bacchus, to whom he intrusted Thebes during his expedition to India</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 131" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 131</bibl> and 167. <cb n="O." /></sense></entryFree>
o: <entryFree id="n31559" type="main" key="O1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">O</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">o</orth>, <itype>the fourteenth letter of the Latin alphabet</itype>, corresponding to the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">o</foreign> and <foreign lang="greek">w</foreign>. The Latin language possessed both the sound and the sign from the earliest times; whereas the Etruscan language never possessed the <sense id="n31559.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">o</hi>, and the Umbrian seems not to have received it as an alphabetical character till a later period. The oldest monuments of the Latin tongue frequently employ <hi rend="ital">o</hi> where the classic language has <hi rend="ital">u</hi>. So on the Column. Rostr. MACESTRATOS (<hi rend="ital">acc. plur.</hi>), EXFOCIONT, CONSOL, PRIMOS (<hi rend="ital">nom. sing.</hi>), CAPTOM; in the epitaphs of the Scipios, HONC OINO, COSENTIONT, DVONORO OPTVMO VIRO (bonorum optumum virum); in the S. C. de Bacch. IN OQVOLTOD al. And even in the later inscrr. and MSS., we sometimes find <hi rend="ital">o</hi> for <hi rend="ital">u</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">POPLICO, POPOLVM, TABOLEIS, in the Tab. Bantina: FACIONDAM DEDERONT,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 1585</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">MONDO, HOC TOMOLO,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 4858</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fondus, fornacatibus, solitodo, etc., in good MSS. (v. Freund,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:page=18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mil. p. 18</bibl></cit>). And, on the contrary, <hi rend="ital">u</hi> for <hi rend="ital">o</hi> in the old forms, fruns, funtes, for frons, fontes, v. h. vv.: RVBVSTIS for robustis, in the Cenot. Pisan.; v. <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 642</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">NVMENCLATOR,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Grut.</author> 630, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">CONSVBRINVS,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 1107, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">SACERDVS,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 34, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">VNV LOCV,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 840, 1</bibl></cit>. <hi rend="ital">O</hi> appears in class. Lat. particularly in connection with <hi rend="ital">qu</hi> and <hi rend="ital">v</hi>: quom, avos. This interchange of <hi rend="ital">o</hi> and <hi rend="ital">u</hi> seems to have been effected rather by dialectical and local than by organic and historical causes; just as in the modern Italian dialects a preference is shown on the one hand for <hi rend="ital">o</hi> and on the other for <hi rend="ital">u</hi>, and in one and the same dialect the Latin <hi rend="ital">o</hi> has passed over into <hi rend="ital">u</hi> and the <hi rend="ital">u</hi> into <hi rend="ital">o</hi>. —On the commutation of <hi rend="ital">o</hi> and <hi rend="ital">e</hi>, see the letter E.—We have <hi rend="ital">o</hi> for <hi rend="ital">au</hi> in Clodius, plodo, plostrum, sodes, etc. (also in polulum for paululum, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 10, 2</bibl>).— <hi rend="ital">O</hi> inserted in the archaic forms: <cit><quote lang="la">Patricoles, Hercoles, v. Ritschl ap. Rhein. Mus. 8, p. 475 sq., and 9, p. 480. As an abbreviation, O. stands for omnis and optimus: I. O. M., Jovi Optimo Maximo: O. E. B. Q. C., ossa ejus bene quiescant condita,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 4489</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">O. I. B. Q., ossa illius bene quiescant,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 4483</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">4490</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">O. N. F., omnium nomine faciundae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 4415</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">O. T. B. Q., ossa tua bene quiescant: O. V., optimo viro,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 4135</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">also: optimi viri,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 5037</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n31560" type="main" key="o_2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ō</orth> (long also before an initial vowel: <sense id="n31560.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">o ego,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 51</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:301" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 301</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">but also short: ŏ Alexi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:2:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 2, 65</bibl></cit>), <pos>interj.</pos> The commonest exclamation of joy, astonishment,<pb n="1232" /> <cb n="OB" />  desire, grief, indignation, etc.; <hi rend="ital">O! Oh!</hi> constr. usually with <case>voc.</case> or <hi rend="ital">acc.;</hi> less freq. with <hi rend="ital">nom., gen., utinam, si.</hi> </sense><sense id="n31560.1" n="1" level="3"> With <hi rend="ital">voc.</hi>: o Romule, Romule die, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:41" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 1, 41</bibl> Vahl. (Ann. v. 115 Vahl.): o Tite, tute Tuti, id. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 947</bibl> P. (Ann. v. 113 Vahl.); cf.: o Tite, si quid te adjuero, id. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:1:1" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 1, 1</bibl> (Ann. v. 339 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">o mi Furni!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:10:26:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 10, 26, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">o paterni generis oblite,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:26:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 26, 62</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31560.2" n="2" level="3"> With <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">o faciem pulchram ... o infortunatum senem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:2:3:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 2, 3, 5</bibl></cit> and 7: <cit><quote lang="la">o miseras hominum mentes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">o me perditum, o me afflictum!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:14:4:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 14, 4, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">o hominem nequam!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:4:13:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 4, 13, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">o praeclarum custodem ovium, ut aiunt, lupum!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:3:11:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 3, 11, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">o rem totam odiosam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 6, 4, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">o Bruti amanter seriptas, litteras,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 15, 10</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n31560.3" n="3" level="3"> With <case>nom.</case> (rare): o pietas animi, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 27, 88</bibl> (Ann. v. 8 Vahl.): o Patricoles, id. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:16:38" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 16, 38</bibl> (Trag. v. 14 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">o vir fortis atque amicus!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:2:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 2, 2, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">o ego ter felix,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 51</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">o ego,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:301" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 301</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">o multum miseri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:155" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 155</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">o qualis facies!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:10:157" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 10, 157</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31560.4" n="4" level="3"> With <hi rend="ital">utinam</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">o utinam Obrutus esset!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 1, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:363 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 1, 363 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n31560.5" n="5" level="3"> With <hi rend="ital">si</hi>: quamquam, o si solitae quicquam virtutis adesset! <hi rend="ital">yet oh! if</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:415" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 415</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31560.6" n="6" level="3"> With <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">o nuntii beati,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:9:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 9, 5</bibl></cit>.—By poets also placed after a word: <cit><quote lang="la">o lux Dardaniae, spes o fidissima Teucrūm,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:281" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 281</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid o tua fulmina cessant!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:279" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 279</bibl></cit>.—Three times repeated: o pater, o genitor, o sanguen dis oriundum, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:41" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 1, 41</bibl> (Ann. v. 117 Vahl.); cf.: o pater, o patria, o Priami domus, id. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:19:44" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 19, 44</bibl> (Trag. v. 118 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">o soror, o conjux, o femina sola superstes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:351" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 351</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
oarion: <entryFree id="n31561" type="main" key="O_a^ri^on"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ōărĭon</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)wari/wn</foreign>, a <usg type="style">poet.</usg> collat. form for Orion, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:66:94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 66, 94</bibl>.</entryFree>
oasis: <entryFree id="n31562" type="main" key="O^a^sis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ŏăsis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/oasis</foreign> [orig. a Coptic word], <sense id="n31562.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an inhabited spot, a fertile piece of land in the Libyan desert, an oasis;</hi> esp. <hi rend="ital">the great oasis in Upper Egypt, to which criminals were banished by the emperors</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cod. Just.</author> 9, 47, 26</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:48:22:7:section=5" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 48, 22, 7, § 5</bibl>.— Hence, </sense><sense id="n31562.1" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ŏăsēnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Oasis</hi>: Oasena deportatio, Cod. Th. 9, 32.—</sense><sense id="n31562.2" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ŏăsītes</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">adj., of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Oasis, Oasite</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Oasitae nomi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 9, 9, § 50</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
oaxes: <entryFree id="n31563" type="main" key="O^axes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ŏaxes</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ŏaxis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/oacis</foreign>, <sense id="n31563.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river in Crete</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Axus</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">rapidum Cretae veniemus Oaxen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:1:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 1, 66</bibl></cit>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n31563.1" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ŏaxis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <hi rend="ital">adj., of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to the Oaxes;</hi> <usg type="style">poet.</usg> for <hi rend="ital">Cretan</hi>: capiens tellurem Oaxida, Varr. Atacin. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> Verg. E. 1, 66</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ob: <entryFree id="n31564" type="main" key="o^b"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏb</orth> (old form <orth extent="full" lang="la">obs</orth>, v. III.), <pos>prep.</pos> with <case>acc.</case> (in late Lat. also with the <case>abl.</case>: <sense id="n31564.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">OB PERPETVO EIVS ERGA SE AMORE,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 106</bibl></cit>) [Osc. op; kindr. with Sanscr. api; Gr. <foreign lang="greek">e)pi/</foreign>]. </sense><sense id="n31564.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n31564.2" n="A" level="2"> With verbs of motion, <hi rend="ital">towards, to</hi> (only ante-class.): IS TERTHS DIEBVS OB PORTVM OBVAGVLATVM ITO, <hi rend="ital">let him go before his house to summon him</hi>, Fragm. XII. Tab. ap. Paul. ex Fest. s. v. portum, p. 233 Müll.: ob Romam legiones ducere, Enn. ap. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=179" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 179</bibl> Müll. (Ann. v. 295 Vahl.); cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">ob Troiam duxit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:ib" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit> p. 178 Müll. (Incert. libr. v. 5 Vahl.): cujus ob os Grai ora obvertebant sua, Poët. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:18:39" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 18, 39</bibl>; and ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:26:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 26, 2</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 211 Rib.).—</sense><sense id="n31564.3" n="B" level="2"> With verbs of rest, <hi rend="ital">about, before, in front of, over</hi> (in Cic.): <cit><quote lang="la">follem sibi obstringit ob gulam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:4:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 2, 4, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lanam ob oculum habere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:5:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 5, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ob oculos mihi caliginem obstitisse,</quote> <trans><tr>before my eyes</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 4, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mors ob oculos saepe versata est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,030:14:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rab. Post. 14, 39</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:21:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sest. 21, 47</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignis qui est ob os offusus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,072:chapter=14" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Univ. 14</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31564.4" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, to indicate the object or cause, <hi rend="ital">on account of, for, because of, by reason of</hi>, etc. </sense><sense id="n31564.5" n="A" level="2"> In gen. (freq. and class.): <cit><quote lang="la">etiam ob stultitiam tuam te tueris?</quote> <trans><tr>do you still defend yourself with regard to your folly?</tr></trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:3:2:82" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 3, 2, 82</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pretium ob stultitiam fero,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:5:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 3, 5, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:2:3:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phorm. 2, 3, 23</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ob eam rem iratus,</quote> <trans><tr>on that account</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:4:4:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 4, 4, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">neu quid ob eam rem succenseat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 4, 39</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:5:6:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 5, 6, 7</bibl>: <hi rend="ital">Mi.</hi> Ob eam rem? <hi rend="ital">De.</hi> Ob eam, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5</bibl>. 9, 20: <cit><quote lang="la">ob rem nullam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:5:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Hec. 5, 3, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hanc Epicurus rationem induxit ob eam rem, quod veritus est, ne, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,054:10:23" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fat. 10, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ob eam causam, quod, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:7:12" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 1, 7, 12</bibl></cit>: quam ob causam venerant,<cb n="OBAE" />  <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:7:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 7, 26</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">non solum ob eam causam fieri volui, quod, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:21:34" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 1, 21, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ob hanc causam, quod,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec ob aliam causam ullam, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:20:74" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 20, 74</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ob meas injurias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:1:1:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 1, 1, 85</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">quodnam ob facinus?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 2, 3</bibl></cit>: ob peccatum hoc. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl> v. 37: <cit><quote lang="la">ob malefacta haec,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:2:1:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ad. 2, 1, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ob illam injuriam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:25:46" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 2, 25, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ob aliquod emolumentum suum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,007:8:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Font. 8, 17</bibl></cit>: (eum) ac Troiam misi ob defendendam Graeciam, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:13:28" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 13, 28</bibl> (Trag. v. 362 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">ob rem judicandam pecuniam adcipere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:32:section=78" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 32, § 78</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:17:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 1, 17, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mur. 1, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:48:section=119" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 48, § 119</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 89:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 89, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:10:87" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 5, 10, 87</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec meliores ob eam scientiam nec beatiores esse possumus,</quote> <trans><tr>on account of, for that knowledge</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:19:32" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 1, 19, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ob eam (amicitiam) summā fide servatam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:7:25" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 7, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">is igitur dicitur ab Amulio ob labefactandi regni timorem, ad Tiberim exponi jussus esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:2:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 2, 2, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">unius ob iram Prodimur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:251" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 251</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">saevae memorem Junonis ob iram,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 4</bibl></cit>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">also: aut ob avaritiam aut miserā ambitione laborat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:4:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 4, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">barbarus eum quidam palam ob iram interfecti ab eo domini obtruncat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 2, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non noxā neque ob metum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 49</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Germanicum mortem ob rem publicam obiisse,</quote> <trans><tr>for the republic</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 2, 83</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum quibus ob rem pecuniariam disceptabat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 5</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31564.6" n="B" level="2"> In partic. </sense><sense id="n31564.7" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">In consideration of, in return for, instead of</hi> (mostly ante-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">ob asinos ferre argentum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:2:2:80" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 2, 2, 80</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:5:2:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 5, 2, 38</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quin arrhabonem a me accepisti ob mulierem?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:3:6:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 3, 6, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ager oppositus est pignori Ob decem minas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:4:3:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 4, 3, 56</bibl></cit>: talentum magnum ob unam fabulam datum esse, C. Gracch. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:11:10" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 11, 10 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecuniam ob absolvendum accipere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:32:section=78" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 32, § 78</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecuniam ob delicta dare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:14:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 14, 14</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31564.8" n="2" level="3"> Ob rem, like ex re (opp. frustra), <hi rend="ital">to the purpose, with advantage, profitably, usefully</hi> (very rare): <hi rend="ital">An.</hi> Non pudet Vanitatis? <hi rend="ital">Do.</hi> Minime, dum ob rem, Ter Phorm. 3, 2, 41: <cit><quote lang="la">verum id frustra an ob rem faciam, in vostrā manu situm est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 31:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 31, 5</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31564.9" n="3" level="3"> Ob industriam, <hi rend="ital">on purpose, intentionally</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:4:3:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 4, 3, 6</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 3, 58</bibl> (<bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 3, 60</bibl>, de industriā); cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:1:2:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. 1, 2, 14</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31564.10" n="4" level="3"> Quam ob rem, also written in one word, quamobrem, <hi rend="ital">on which account, wherefore, therefore, hence, accordingly;</hi> a very freq. particle of transition, esp. in Cic.: <cit><quote lang="la">quam ob rem id primum videamus, quatenus, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:11:36" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 11, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quam ob rem utrique nostrūm gratum admodum feceris,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 16</bibl></cit>; 2, 10; 3, 12; 4, 15; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:5:9" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 1, 5, 9</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 19, 32</bibl> et saep.—</sense><sense id="n31564.11" n="5" level="3"> Ob id, ob hoc, ob haec, ob ea, ob quae, <hi rend="ital">on that account, therefore</hi> (not ante-Aug.). </sense><sense id="n31564.12" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Ob id</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignaris hostibus et ob id quietis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 25, 35</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:2" default="NO" valid="yes">28, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 66</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 75</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">13, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ob id ipsum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:16:23" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 16, 23</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31564.13" n="b" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Ob hoc</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ob hoc cum omnia neglecta apud hostes essent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 25, 37</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Q. N. 7:14:4" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Q. N. 7, 14, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:7:3:21" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 7, 3, 21</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">ob hoc miserior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 98:5" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 98, 5</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n31564.14" n="c" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Ob haec</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ob haec cum legatos mitti placuisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 23</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:50" default="NO" valid="yes">21, 50</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:34" default="NO" valid="yes">38, 34</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:1 praef" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 1 praef.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n31564.15" n="d" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Ob ea</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ob ea consul Albinus senatum de foedere consulebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 39:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 39, 2</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31564.16" n="e" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Ob quae</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ob quae posterum diem reus petivit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 30 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:13" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 13</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31564.17" n="III" level="1"> In composition, the <hi rend="ital">b</hi> of ob remains unchanged before vowels and most consonants; only before <hi rend="ital">p, f, c, g</hi>, is assimilation more common: oppeto, offero, occido, ogganio, etc.—An ancient form obs, analogous to abs, is implied in obs-olesco and os-tendo.—In signification, that of direction <hi rend="ital">towards</hi>, or of existence <hi rend="ital">at</hi> or <hi rend="ital">before</hi> a thing is predominant, although it likewise gives to the simple verb the accessory notion of <hi rend="ital">against</hi>: obicere, opponere, obrogare.</sense></entryFree>
obacerbat: <entryFree id="n31565" type="gloss" key="o^ba^cerbat"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏbăcerbat</orth>, <itype>exacerbat</itype>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=187" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 187</bibl> Müll.</entryFree>
obacero: <entryFree id="n31566" type="gloss" key="o^ba^ce^ro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏbăcĕro</orth>, <itype>1</itype>, <sense id="n31566.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. a., to contradict, interrupt</hi>: obacerare obloqui atque alterius sermonem moleste impedire; quod sumptum videtur a paleis, quas Graeci <foreign lang="greek">a)/xura</foreign> vocant, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=187" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 187</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
obaemulor: <entryFree id="n31567" type="main" key="o^baemu^lor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏb-aemŭlor</orth>, <itype>1</itype>, <sense id="n31567.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. dep. n.</hi> (lit. to excite to jealousy against, i. e.), <hi rend="ital">to stir up, irritate, provoke</hi> (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">illi obaemulati sunt me in non Deo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Marc. 4, 31</bibl></cit> (a translation of Deut. 32, 21). <cb n="OBBA" /></sense></entryFree>
obaerarius: <entryFree id="n31568" type="hapax" key="o^baera_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏbaerārĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>ob-aes</etym>, <sense id="n31568.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a debtor who must work out his debt</hi> (ante-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">(agros colunt) ii, quos obaerarios nostri vocitārunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:17:2" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 17, 2</bibl></cit> Schneid. <hi rend="ital">N. cr</hi>.</sense></entryFree>
obaeratus: <entryFree id="n31569" type="main" key="o^baera_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏb-aerātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n31569.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">involved in debt, in bondage on account of debt</hi> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">liber, qui suas operas in servitute pro pecuniā quādam debebat, dum solveret, nexus vocatur, ut ab aere obaeratus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:section=105" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, § 105</bibl></cit> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">tenuis et obaeratus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:46" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 46</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quanto quis obaeratior, aegrius distrahebant,</quote> <trans><tr>the more deeply in debt</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 17</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31569.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏbaerā-tus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a person involved in debt, a debtor</hi>: obaeratos liberare, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:21:38" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 2, 21, 38</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Orgetorix omnes clientes obaeratosque suos eodem conduxit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:40:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 40, 17</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obambulatio: <entryFree id="n31570" type="hapax" key="o^bambu^la_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏb-ambŭlātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>obambulo</etym>, <sense id="n31570.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a going</hi> or <hi rend="ital">walking about</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">obambulatio hominum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 3, 19, 31</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obambulo: <entryFree id="n31571" type="main" key="o^bambu^lo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏb-ambŭlo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> and <sense id="n31571.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a., to walk before</hi> or <hi rend="ital">near</hi> any thing, <hi rend="ital">to go past</hi> (not in Cic. or Cæs.); constr. with <case>dat.</case> or <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: obambulare adversum alios ambulare, et quasi ambulanti sese opponere, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=187" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 187</bibl> Müll. </sense><sense id="n31571.1" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">obambulare muris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:36:34:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 36, 34, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gymnasio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:11" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 11</bibl></cit>: nec (lupus) gregibus nocturnus obambulat, <hi rend="ital">walk</hi> or <hi rend="ital">prowl about</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:538" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 538</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31571.2" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">urbem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:4:4:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 4, 4, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">totam fremebundus obambulat Aetnam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:188" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 188</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gymnasia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:11" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 11</bibl></cit> (al. gymnasio).—</sense><sense id="n31571.3" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, in gen., <hi rend="ital">to go</hi> or <hi rend="ital">walk about, wander</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">neu noctu irem obambulatum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:2:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 2, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ante vallum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 25, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sermone imperfecto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:3:121" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 11, 3, 121</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in herbis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:851" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 851</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praeter os,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:prol. 19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. prol. 19</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum solus obambulet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:2:459" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 2, 459</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:25" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 25</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obarator: <entryFree id="n31572" type="main" key="O^ba^ra_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ŏb-ărātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n31572.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the god of ploughing</hi>, Fab. Pict. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. G. 1, 21</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obardesco: <entryFree id="n31573" type="hapax" key="o^bardesco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏb-ardesco</orth>, <itype>arsi, 3</itype>, <sense id="n31573.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. inch. n., to burn before</hi> one, <hi rend="ital">to blaze out</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">obarsit Dryas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:9:856" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 9, 856</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obaresco: <entryFree id="n31574" type="main" key="o^ba_resco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏb-āresco</orth>, <itype>ĕre</itype>, <sense id="n31574.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. inch. n., to grow dry, to dry up</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">membrana quam siccari et obarescere non oportet,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> Opif. D. 10, 3</bibl></cit> (al. arescere).</sense></entryFree>
obarmo: <entryFree id="n31575" type="main" key="o^barmo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏb-armo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <sense id="n31575.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. a., to arm</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg> and post-class.). </sense><sense id="n31575.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">securi Dextras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:4:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 4, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">clipeo filium,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Epigr. 25, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">manus impias contra aliquem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 9 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n31575.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">perfrictis oculis, et obarmatis ad vigilias,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 2, p. 125, 28</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obaro: <entryFree id="n31576" type="hapax" key="o^ba^ro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏb-ăro</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <sense id="n31576.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. n., to plough around, plough up</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum hostes obarāssent quicquid herbidi terreni extra murum erat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:19:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 23, 19, 14</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obatratus: <entryFree id="n31577" type="hapax" key="o^ba_tra_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏb-ātrātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n31577.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj., obscured, black, blackish</hi>: nascens luna si cornu superiore obatrato surget, pluvias decrescens dabit, Varr. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:349" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 35, 79, § 349</bibl> Sillig. <hi rend="ital">N. cr.</hi> (al. obatro).</sense></entryFree>
obatresco: <entryFree id="n31578" type="hapax" key="o^ba_tresco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏb-ātresco</orth>, <itype>ĕre</itype>, <sense id="n31578.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. inch. n.</hi> [obatratus], <hi rend="ital">to become black</hi>, Firm. Math. praef.</sense></entryFree>
obaudiens: <entryFree id="n31579" type="main" key="o^baudi^ens"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏb-audĭens</orth>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, v. obaudio <sense id="n31579.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
obaudientia: <entryFree id="n31580" type="main" key="o^baudi^enti^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏb-audĭentĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>obaudio</etym>, <sense id="n31580.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">obedience</hi> (eccl. Lat. for the class. oboedientia), <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Exhort. ad Cast. 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obaudio: <entryFree id="n31581" type="main" key="o^baudi^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏb-audĭo</orth>, <itype>ii, 4</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, for oboedio, <sense id="n31581.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to obey</hi> (post-class.); constr. with <case>dat.</case> or <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> </sense><sense id="n31581.1" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">alicui,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 3, p. 136, 11</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n31581.2" n="(b)" level="5"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">Adam non obaudiit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Marc. 2, 2</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">obaudite me,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Eccles. 39, 17</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏbaudĭens</orth>, <itype>entis</itype>, <hi rend="ital">P. a., obedient</hi> (eccl. Lat. for oboediens).— <hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid obaudientius esse potest, quam ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ambros.</author> Ep. 21</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obauditio: <entryFree id="n31582" type="gloss" key="o^baudi_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏbaudītĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>obaudio</etym>, <sense id="n31582.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">obedience</hi>: obauditio, <foreign lang="greek">u/pakoh/</foreign>, Gloss. Philox.</sense></entryFree>
obauditus: <entryFree id="n31583" type="main" key="o^baudi_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏbaudītus</orth>, <case>abl.</case>, <itype>ū</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n31583.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a listening</hi>: auris, Aug. Civ. Dei, 22, 29.</sense></entryFree>
obauratus: <entryFree id="n31584" type="main" key="o^baura_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏb-aurātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n31584.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj., gilded</hi> (postclass.): <cit><quote lang="la">socci obaurati,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 11, p. 260, 34</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obba: <entryFree id="n31585" type="main" key="obba1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obba</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, a vessel large at the bottom, <sense id="n31585.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a beaker, noggin; a decanter</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">obba poculi genus, quod nunc ubba dicitur. Varro: obbas et Cumanos calices,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 146, 8 sq.</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">obba poculi genus vel ligneum vel ex sparto. Varro (here follows the passage just cited): idem Epistola ad Marullium: utrum meridie an vesperi libentius ad obbam accedas,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 545, 2 sq.</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:5" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 5</bibl>, <pb n="1233" /> <cb n="OBDU" /> 148; <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Apol. 13</bibl>. (But in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 7, 10, § 53</bibl>, the correct read. is phoba, v. Sillig. ad h. l.)</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n31586" type="main" key="Obba2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Obba</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n31586.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city in Africa near Carthage</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:7:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 30, 7, 10</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obbatus: <entryFree id="n31587" type="spur" key="obba_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obbātus</orth>, false read. for ovatae, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 10, p. 254, 15</bibl>.</entryFree>
obblateratus: <entryFree id="n31588" type="spur" key="obbla^te^ra_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-blătĕrātus</orth>, false read. for adblaterantes, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 9, p. 221, 25</bibl>.</entryFree>
obbrutesco: <entryFree id="n31589" type="main" key="obbru_tesco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-brūtesco</orth>, <itype>tŭi, 3</itype>, <sense id="n31589.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. inch. n., to become brutish, stupid</hi> (ante- and post-class.): obbrutuit, obstupuit, a bruto, quod antiqui pro gravi, interdum pro stupido dixerunt. Afranius: non possum verbum facere, obbrutui, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=187" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 187</bibl> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">anima contracta suis e partibus obbrutescat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:545" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 545</bibl></cit> (also ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 77, 32</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">claude meatus Obbrutescentis capitis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> Hamart. 652</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obc: <entryFree id="n31590" type="main" key="obc"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obc-</orth>, v. occ-.</entryFree>
obdensatio: <entryFree id="n31591" type="main" key="obdensa_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-densātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n31591.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a thickening</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">cutis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Tard. 1:1:47" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Tard. 1, 1, 47</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obditus: <entryFree id="n31592" type="main" key="obdi^tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obdĭtus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood>, v. obdo.</entryFree>
obdo: <entryFree id="n31593" type="main" key="obdo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-do</orth>, <itype>dĭdi, dĭtum, 3</itype>, <sense id="n31593.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. a., to put, place</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">set</hi> one thing <hi rend="ital">before</hi> another; <hi rend="ital">to put against; to shut, close, fasten</hi>, etc.: obdere, opponere vel operire, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=191" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 191</bibl> Müll.
