obliquoloquus: <entryFree id="n31694" type="gloss" key="Obli_quo^lo^quus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Oblīquŏlŏquus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>obliquus-loquor</etym>, <sense id="n31694.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one who speaks indirectly</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">ambiguously</hi>, an epithet of Apollo, acc. to the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">*loci/as</foreign>, in allusion to his obscure oracles: Obliquoloquus, <foreign lang="greek">*loci/as</foreign>, Gloss. Philox.</sense></entryFree>
obliquus: <entryFree id="n31695" type="main" key="obli_quus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">oblīquus</orth> (<orth extent="full" lang="la">oblīcus</orth>, v. Orthogr. Vergl. p. 449 Wagner), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>ob and liquus; root lek-; Gr. <foreign lang="greek">le/xrios, le/xris</foreign>, slantwise (cf.: <foreign lang="greek">loco/s, *loci/as</foreign>); Lat. licinus, limus, luxus, luxare</etym>, <sense id="n31695.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">sidelong, slanting, awry, oblique</hi> (freq. and class.; cf.: transversus, imus). </sense><sense id="n31695.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">motus corporis, pronus, obliquus, supinus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:53:120" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 53, 120</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hos partim obliquos, partim aversos, partim etiam adversos stare vobis,</quote> <trans><tr>on one side of you, sideways</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:6:19:20" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 6, 19, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obliquo claudicare pede,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:2:17:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 2, 17, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sublicae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:4:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 4, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ordines,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 73</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">iter,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. C. 1, 70</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obliquam facere imaginem,</quote> <trans><tr>a side-likeness, profile</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:90" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 10, 36, § 90</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">chordae,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>of the triangular harp</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:3:64" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 3, 64</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">verris obliquum meditantis ictum Sanguine donare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:22:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 22, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obliquo dente timendus aper,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:4:104" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 4, 104</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rex aquarum cursibus obliquis fluens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 9, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">radix,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:10:491" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 10, 491</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obliquo capite speculari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:88" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 24, 36, § 88</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non istic obliquo oculo mea commoda quisquam Limat,</quote> <trans><tr>with a sidelong glance, an envious look</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 14, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non obliquis oculis sed circumacto capite cernere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:151" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 37, 55, § 151</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obliquoque notat Proserpina vultu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:2:6:102" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 2, 6, 102</bibl></cit>.— Adverbial phrases: ab obliquo, ex obliquo, per obliquum, in obliquum, obliquum, <hi rend="ital">from the side, sideways, not straight on</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab obliquo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> R. Am. 121</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec supra ipsum nec infra, sed ex obliquo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:99" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 31, 31, § 99</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">serpens per obliquum similis sagittae Terruit mannos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:27:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 27, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cancri in obliquom aspiciunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:152" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 37, 55, § 152</bibl></cit>: obliquum, <hi rend="ital">obliquely, askance</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">oculis obliquum respiciens,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 3, p. 140</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quia positio signiferi circa media sui obliquior est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:188" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 77, 79, § 188</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31695.2" n="II" level="1"> Fig. </sense><sense id="n31695.3" n="A" level="2"> Of relationship, <hi rend="ital">not direct, collateral</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg> and late Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">obliquum a patre genus,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>not born of the same mother with myself</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:5:221" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 5, 221</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obliquo maculat qui sanguine regnum,</quote> <trans><tr>by collateral consanguinity</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:8:286" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 8, 286</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">tertio gradu veniunt ... ex obliquo fratris sororisque filius,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul.</author> Sent. 4, 11, 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31695.4" n="B" level="2"> Of speech. </sense><sense id="n31695.5" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Indirect, covert</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">obliquis orationibus carpere aliquem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=dom.:2" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Dom. 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">insectatio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:14:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 14, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dicta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Epit. 9" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Epit. 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">verba,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 15, 5, 4</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31695.6" n="2" level="3"> In a bad sense, <hi rend="ital">envious, hostile</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">Cato adversus potentes semper obliquus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:4:2:9" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 4, 2, 9</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31695.7" n="3" level="3"> In gram. </sense><sense id="n31695.8" n="a" level="4"> Obliquus casus, <hi rend="ital">an oblique case</hi> (i. e. all the cases except the <case>nom.</case> and <case>voc.</case>), opp. rectus: <cit><quote lang="la">alia casus habent et rectos et obliquos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 8:section=49" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 8, § 49</bibl></cit> Müll.—</sense><sense id="n31695.9" n="b" level="4"> Obliqua oratio, <hi rend="ital">indirect speech</hi>: apud historicos reperiuntur obliquae allocutiones, ut in T. Livii primo statim libro (c. 9): urbes quoque, ut cetera, ex infimo nasci; <cit><quote lang="la">deinde, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:2:37" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 2, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oratio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:38:3:11" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 38, 3, 11</bibl></cit>.— <itype>Hence</itype>, <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">oblīquē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">sideways, athwart, obliquely</hi>. </sense><sense id="n31695.10" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">quae (atomi) recte, quae oblique ferantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:6:20" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 1, 6, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sublicae oblique agebantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:4:17:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 4, 17, 9</bibl></cit>: procedere. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:95" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 30, 50, § 95</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">situs signifer,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 15, 13, § 63</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31695.11" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">indirectly, covertly</hi> (post-Aug.): <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem castigare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">perstringere aliquem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admonere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:3:2:16" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 3, 2, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:7:17:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 7, 17, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obliscor: <entryFree id="n31696" type="main" key="obliscor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obliscor</orth>, <itype>oblisci</itype>, paragog. obliscier, archaic collat. form of obliviscor, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 500, 1</bibl> (Trag. Rel. v. 190 Rib.).—<sense id="n31696.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Fut.</hi>: obliscar, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 500, 1</bibl> (Trag. Rel. v. 488 Rib.); v. obliviscor. <cb n="OBLI" /></sense></entryFree>
oblisus: <entryFree id="n31697" type="main" key="obli_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">oblīsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood>, from oblido.</entryFree>
oblitesco: <entryFree id="n31698" type="main" key="obli^tesco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-lĭtesco</orth>, <itype>tŭi, 3</itype>, <sense id="n31698.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. inch. n.</hi> [latesco], <hi rend="ital">to hide</hi> or <hi rend="ital">conceal one's self</hi> (rare but class.): <cit><quote lang="la">a nostro aspectu oblitescant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,072:10:33" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Univ. 10, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne in rimis (areae) grana oblitescant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:51:1" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 51, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui velut timidum atque iners animal metu oblituit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 55:5" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 55, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Q. N. 7:29:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Q. N. 7, 29, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
oblitor: <entryFree id="n31699" type="main" key="obli_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">oblītor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>obliviscor; but perh. from oblino, a defiler</etym>, <sense id="n31699.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a forgetter</hi> (late Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">judiciorum oblitores,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hier.</author> in Psa. 88</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
oblitteratio: <entryFree id="n31700" type="main" key="oblitte^ra_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-littĕrātĭo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">oblīt-</orth>), <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>oblittero</etym>, <sense id="n31700.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a blotting out, erasing, effacing, obliteration;</hi> and, in partic., <hi rend="ital">a blotting out from the memory, a forgetting, forgetfulness</hi> (postAug.): <cit><quote lang="la">aeris oblitteratio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 34, 7, 18, § 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vetustatis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 6, 194</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praeteritorum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 30, 6, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
oblitterator: <entryFree id="n31701" type="main" key="oblitte^ra_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-littĕrātor</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">oblīt-</orth>), <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n31701.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a blotter out, obliterator</hi>, sc. from the memory (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">commemorator, non oblitterator vetustatum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Marc. 4, 26 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul. Nol.</author> Ep. 16, 7</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
oblittero: <entryFree id="n31702" type="main" key="oblitte^ro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">oblittĕro</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">oblīt-</orth>), <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>oblino</etym>, <sense id="n31702.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to blot out, strike out, erase, obliterate</hi>. </sense><sense id="n31702.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> (post-Aug. and very rare; <cit><quote lang="la">syn. deleo): oblitterata aerarii monumenta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:13:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 13, 23 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n31702.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to blot out of remembrance, consign to oblivion, cause to be forgotten</hi> (esp. freq. in post-Aug. prose; principally in Tac.): inimicitias Pelopidarum exstinctā tam oblitteratas memoriā renovare, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 146, 30</bibl> (oblitterare est obscurefacere et in oblivionem ducere, <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 146, 28</bibl>); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,023:6:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Vatin. 6, 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">famam rei,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 39, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 71</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">memoriam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 21, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mandata,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:64:232" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 64, 232</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rem silentio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:22" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne ritus sacrorum oblitterarentur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:11:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 11, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">conjugia,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oblitterari in animo,</quote> <trans><tr>to become forgotten</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 41</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
oblitterus: <entryFree id="n31703" type="hapax" key="oblitte^rus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">oblittĕrus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">oblīt-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, for oblitteratus, <sense id="n31703.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">consigned to forgetfulness, forgotten</hi> (ante-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">Laevius oblitteram gentem pro oblitteratam dixit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:19:7:4" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 19, 7, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
oblitus: <entryFree id="n31704" type="main" key="obli^tus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">oblĭtus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood>, from oblino.</entryFree>
<entryFree id="n31705" type="main" key="obli_tus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">oblītus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood>, from obliviscor.</entryFree>
oblivialis: <entryFree id="n31706" type="main" key="obli_vi^a_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">oblīvĭālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>oblivio</etym>, <sense id="n31706.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that causes forgetfulness, oblivious</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">poculum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> Cath. 6, 16</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
oblivio: <entryFree id="n31707" type="main" key="obli_vi^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">oblīvĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>obliviscor</etym>. <sense id="n31707.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a being forgotten, forgetfulness, oblivion</hi> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">oblivio veteris belli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:chapter=4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Imp. Pomp. 4 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">laudem alicujus ab oblivione atque a silentio vindicare,</quote> <trans><tr>to rescue from oblivion</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:2:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 2, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">meam tuorum erga me meritorum memoriam nulla umquam delebit oblivio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 2, 1, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dare aliquid oblivioni,</quote> <trans><tr>to consign to oblivion</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:31:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 31, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oblivione obruere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:15:60" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 15, 60</bibl></cit>; for which (late Lat.): oblivioni tradere, Aug. Civ. Dei, 18, 31, 2; <bibl default="NO"><author>Hier.</author> in Psa. 68, 1 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnes ejus injurias voluntariā quādam oblivione contriveram,</quote> <trans><tr>had consigned to oblivion</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:9:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 1, 9, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in oblivionem negoti venire,</quote> <trans><tr>to forget</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:35:section=79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 35, § 79</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">satius erat ista in oblivionem ire,</quote> <trans><tr>to be forgotten</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Brev. Vit. 13:7" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Brev. Vit. 13, 7 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in oblivionem diuturnitate adduci,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:17:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 1, 17, 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">capit me oblivio alicujus rei,</quote> <trans><tr>I forget something</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:8:26" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 8, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">per oblivionem,</quote> <trans><tr>through forgetfulness</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:28" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in oblivione est,</quote> <trans><tr>is forgotten</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:12:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Luc. 12, 6</bibl></cit>.—In <number>plur.</number>: <cit><quote lang="la">carpere lividas Obliviones,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:9:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 9, 34</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:9:5:6" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 9, 5, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:Decl. 306" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> Decl. 306</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31707.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n31707.2" n="A" level="2"> Subject., <hi rend="ital">a forgetting, forgetfulness</hi> (post-Aug.): <cit><quote lang="la">in eo (Claudio) mirati sunt homines et oblivionem et inconsiderantiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:39" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 39</bibl></cit>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:11:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 11, 38</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31707.3" n="B" level="2"> Concr </sense><sense id="n31707.4" n="1" level="3"> Oblivio litterarum, <hi rend="ital">a <usg type="style">poet.</usg> designation of</hi> Orbilius Pupillus, <hi rend="ital">a grammarian, who lost his memory in his old age</hi>, Bibacul. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,004:9" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Gram. 9</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31707.5" n="2" level="3"> Flumen Oblivionis, <hi rend="ital">an appellation of the river</hi> Limia, <hi rend="ital">in</hi> Hispania Tarraconensis, acc. to the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">o( th=s lh/qhs</foreign>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:3:1:8" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 3, 1, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:2:17:12" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 2, 17, 12</bibl>; called flumen Oblivio, Liv Epit. 55.</sense></entryFree>
obliviosus: <entryFree id="n31708" type="main" key="obli_vi^o_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">oblīvĭōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>oblivio</etym>. <sense id="n31708.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">that easily forgets, forgetful, oblivious</hi> (rare but class.): <cit><quote lang="la">hos (senes) significat credulos, obliviosos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:11:36" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 11, 36</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">homo obliviosissimus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Anim. 24</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31708.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">that produces forgetfulness, oblivious</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">Massicus (i. e. sollicitudinum oblivionem afferens),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:7:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 7, 21</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obliviscor: <entryFree id="n31709" type="main" key="obli_viscor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">oblīviscor</orth>, <itype>lītus</itype> (archaic <sense id="n31709.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">inf.</hi> obliscier.<cb n="OBLO" />  <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0400,001:Tr. 190" default="NO"><author>Att.</author> Tr. 190</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0400,001:488" default="NO">488</bibl>), <itype>3</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos> <etym>ob and livor, q. v.; livēre, to become dark; hence, to have the mind darkened, forget</etym>, <hi rend="ital">to forget;</hi> constr. with <hi rend="ital">gen. of pers.</hi> and with <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> or <hi rend="ital">acc. of thing;</hi> less freq. with <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi> or a <hi rend="ital">rel.clause</hi> (class.; cf. dedisco). </sense><sense id="n31709.1" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">gen. of person</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">vivorum memini, nec tamen Epicuri licet oblivisci,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:1:3" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 5, 1, 3</bibl></cit>: nescio hercule, neque unde eam, neque quorsum eam; <cit><quote lang="la">ita prorsum oblitus sum mei,</quote> <trans><tr>I have so completely forgotten myself, been lost in thought</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:2:3:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 2, 3, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">regisque ducumque meique,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:276" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 276</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dum tu ades, sunt oblitae sui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:12:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 12, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec oblitus sui est Ithacus discrimine tanto,</quote> <trans><tr>was not forgetful of himself, untrue to his nature</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:629" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 629</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:3:664" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 3, 664</bibl>: sui, <hi rend="ital">to forget one's self, know nothing of one's former self</hi>, sc. after death, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Herc. Fur. 292" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Herc. Fur. 292</bibl>; also, <hi rend="ital">to forget one's self</hi> in a character represented or assumed: <cit><quote lang="la">tamquam in eo tragoediae argumento sui oblitus tantum Catonem cogitāsset,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tac.</author> Or. 2</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n31709.2" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">gen. of thing</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">meminens naturae et professionis oblitus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 4, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec umquam obliviscar noctis illius, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:42:101" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 42, 101</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">oblivisci temporum meorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:9:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 1, 9, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut nostrae dignitatis simus obliti,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 7, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">veterumque oblitus honorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:543" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 543</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:4:2:5" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 4, 2, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">oblivisci veteris contumeliae, recentium injuriarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">controversiarum ac dissensionum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pristini instituti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. C. 3, 57</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">offensarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tot exemplorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:2:86" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 2, 86</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n31709.3" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">acc. of thing</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui quod dedit id ob litust datum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:2:1:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 2, 1, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">officium meum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:1:1:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cas. 1, 1, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">injurias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:20:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cael. 20, 50</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">artificium obliviscatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:17:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 17, 49</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">res praeclarissimas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:23:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 23, 63</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">totam causam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:60:218" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 60, 218</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec tam crebra Etruriae concilia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 5</bibl></cit>, Drak. <hi rend="ital">N. cr.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut alia obliviscar,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:31:87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 31, 87</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">acc. of person</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">obliti sunt Deum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,027:105:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Psa. 105, 21</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">49, 22</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31709.4" n="(d)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">oblita pharetram tollere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:439" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 439</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">suas quatere pennas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:4:676" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 676</bibl></cit>: dicere aliqu<bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ter. And. 5, 1, 22</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">obliviscor, Roscium et Cluvium viros esse primarios,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,003:17:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Com. 17, 50</bibl></cit>.—（<foreign lang="greek">e</foreign>) With a <hi rend="ital">rel.clause</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in scriptis obliviscebatur, quid paulo ante posuisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:60:218" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 60, 218</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31709.5" n="b" level="4"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, transf., of things: <cit><quote lang="la">saeclis obliviscentibus,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>causing forgetfulness</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:68:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 68, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oblito pectore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:64:207" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 64, 207</bibl></cit>: pomaque degenerant sucos oblita priores, <hi rend="ital">forgetting</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">being deprived of losing</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 59</bibl>; imitated by Col. poët. 10, 408.—</sense><sense id="n31709.6" n="c" level="4"> Prov.: <cit><quote lang="la">oblivisci nomen suum,</quote> <trans><tr>to forget one's own name, to have a bad memory</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 66</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31709.7" n="d" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Part. fut. pass.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">oblitusque meorum, obliviscendus et illis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 11, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obliviscendi stratiotici,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:4:8:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 4, 8, 49</bibl></cit>.!*? In <hi rend="ital">Pass.</hi> signif. (<usg type="style">poet.</usg> and late Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">post emancipationem in totum adoptivae familiae obliviscuntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:23:2:60:section=6" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 23, 2, 60, § 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oblita carmina,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:9:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 9, 53</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:2:388" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 2, 388</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">oblitos superūm dolores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:1:791" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 1, 791</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">suis hominibus oblitus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>August.</author> Mus. 4, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
oblivium: <entryFree id="n31710" type="main" key="obli_vi^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">oblīvĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>obliviscor</etym>, <sense id="n31710.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">forgetfulness, oblivion</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg> and once in Tac. for oblivio; usually in the <number>plur.</number>): <cit><quote lang="la">oblivia rerum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:828" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 828</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:1066" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 1066</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:1213" default="NO" valid="yes">6, 1213</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">longa oblivia potant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:715" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 715</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ducere sollicitae jucunda oblivia vitae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:6:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 6, 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">taedae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:2:628" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 2, 628</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agere oblivia laudis,</quote> <trans><tr>to forget</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:12:539" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 12, 539</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">suci, qui patriae faciant oblivia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:4:10:19" default="NO"><author>id.</author> P. 4, 10, 19</bibl></cit>.— In <number>sing.</number>. sententiam oblivio transmittere, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 9</bibl>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Ambros.</author> Apol. Dav. 31, 16</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
oblivius: <entryFree id="n31711" type="hapax" key="obli_vi^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">oblīvĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>oblivio</etym>, <sense id="n31711.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">sunk into oblivion, forgotten</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">verba,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>obsolete</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=10" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 10</bibl></cit> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
obloco: <entryFree id="n31712" type="main" key="oblo^co"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-lŏco</orth>, <itype>1</itype>, <sense id="n31712.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. a., to let out</hi> for hire (postAug. and post class.): <cit><quote lang="la">operam ad puteos exhauriendos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:11:10:9" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 11, 10, 9</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">v. l. for abloco,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:26" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 26</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
oblocutio: <entryFree id="n31713" type="main" key="oblo^cu_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">oblŏcūtĭo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">-quūtio</orth>), <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>obloquor</etym>, <sense id="n31713.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">contradiction</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cassiod.</author> Var. 4, 31</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
oblocutor: <entryFree id="n31714" type="hapax" key="oblo^cu_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">oblŏcūtor</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">-quūtor</orth>), <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n31714.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a contradicter</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque ego oblocutor sum alteri in convivio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:1:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 3, 1, 48</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
oblongulus: <entryFree id="n31715" type="main" key="oblongu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">oblongŭlus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n31715.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj. dim.</hi> [oblongus], <hi rend="ital">rather long</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">surculi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:17:9:7" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 17, 9, 7</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
oblongus: <entryFree id="n31716" type="main" key="oblongus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-longus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n31716.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj., rather long, longish; oblong</hi> (not in Cic. or Cæs.): <cit><quote lang="la">missile telum hastili oblongo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">figura,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:196" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 12, 75, § 196</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">folia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:3:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 25, 3, 6</bibl></cit>. <pb n="1238" /> <cb n="OBMU" /> § <cit><quote lang="la">21: scutula,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 10</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">foramen oblongius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:21:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 21, 8 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:10:11:4" default="NO" valid="yes">10, 11, 4</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obloquium: <entryFree id="n31717" type="main" key="oblo^qui^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">oblŏquĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>obloquor</etym>, <sense id="n31717.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a contradiction</hi> (post-class.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 7, 9</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obloquor: <entryFree id="n31718" type="main" key="oblo^quor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-lŏquor</orth>, <itype>locūtus, 3</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos> <sense id="n31718.0" n="I" level="1"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">to speak against</hi> a person or thing; <hi rend="ital">to interrupt</hi> a speaker; <hi rend="ital">to gainsay, contradict</hi> (class.; syn. interpello); constr. with <case>dat.</case> or <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> </sense><sense id="n31718.1" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">alicui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:1:2:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 1, 2, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vestra exspectatio, quae mihi obloqui videtur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:23:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 23, 63</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31718.2" n="(b)" level="5"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">obloquere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:1:1:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 1, 1, 41</bibl></cit>: te blaterare atque obloqui? Afran. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 78, 33</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut me et appelles, et interpelles, et obloquare, et colloquare, velim,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:2:10:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 2, 10, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ferocissime,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:10:2:30" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 10, 2, 30</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31718.3" n="II" level="1"> In partic. </sense><sense id="n31718.4" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To sing to, to accompany</hi> or <hi rend="ital">join in singing</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">non avis obloquitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:3:1:21" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 3, 1, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obloquitur numeris septem discrimina vocum,</quote> <trans><tr>mingles the notes of his lute, accompanies on his lute</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:646" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 646</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31718.5" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To blame, condemn</hi> (post-Aug.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 121:4" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 121, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,027:43:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Psa. 43, 17</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31718.6" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To rail at, reproach, abuse</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">quod nunc gannit, et obloquitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:83:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 83, 3</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obloquutio: <entryFree id="n31719" type="main" key="obloquu_tio"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obloquūtio</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">obloquūtor</orth>, v. oblocu-.</entryFree>
oblucinasse: <entryFree id="n31720" type="gloss" key="oblucinasse"><orth extent="full" lang="la">oblucinasse</orth>, v. oblucuviasse.</entryFree>
obluctatio: <entryFree id="n31721" type="main" key="oblucta_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obluctātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>obluctor</etym>, <sense id="n31721.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a striving</hi> or <hi rend="ital">struggling against, vehement opposition</hi> (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">obluctatio virtutis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 2, 77</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">flammarum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 6, § 647</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversus mala,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> 3, 11, 11</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Plur.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quis obluctationes sensit?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ambros.</author> Laps. Virg. 4, 12</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obluctor: <entryFree id="n31722" type="main" key="obluctor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-luctor</orth>, <itype>ātus, 1</itype>, <sense id="n31722.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. dep., to strive</hi> or <hi rend="ital">struggle against, to contend with, oppose</hi> a person or thing (<usg type="style">poet.</usg> and in post-Aug. prose). </sense><sense id="n31722.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n31722.2" n="A" level="2"> With <hi rend="ital">dat. of person</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">soli obluctandum Fabio,</quote> <trans><tr>to contend with Fabius alone</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:8:10" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 8, 10</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31722.3" n="B" level="2"> With <hi rend="ital">dat. of thing</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">genibusque adversae obluctor harenae,</quote> <trans><tr>struggle against</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fruticibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:8:14:8" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 8, 14, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">flumini,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:8:8" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 8, 8</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n31722.4" n="C" level="2"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">obluctantia saxa Submovit nitens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:3:1:20" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 3, 1, 20</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31722.5" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut erat animi semper obluctantis difficultatibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:6:6:27" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 6, 6, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oblivioni,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:7:1:9" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 7, 1, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">morti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:3:662" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 3, 662</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
oblucuviasse: <entryFree id="n31723" type="gloss" key="oblucuviasse"><orth extent="full" lang="la">oblucuviasse</orth> <itype>dicebant antiqui mente errasse, quasi in luco deorum alicui occurrisse</itype>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=187" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 187</bibl> Müll. (al. oblucinasse).</entryFree>
obludo: <entryFree id="n31724" type="main" key="oblu_do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-lūdo</orth>, <itype>si, sum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> * <sense id="n31724.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To play off jokes</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">obludunt, qui custodem oblectent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:1:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 1, 2, 10</bibl></cit>.—* </sense><sense id="n31724.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To make sport of, mock</hi> one; with <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">alicui,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> Hamart. 6</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obluridus: <entryFree id="n31725" type="main" key="oblu_ri^dus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-lūrĭdus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n31725.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj., pale, sallow</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">spadones obluridi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 14, 6, 17</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obmanens: <entryFree id="n31726" type="gloss" key="obma^nens"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obmănens</orth> <itype>pro diu manens, ut permanens</itype>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=199" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 199</bibl> Müll.; and cf. ommento.</entryFree>
obmarcesco: <entryFree id="n31727" type="hapax" key="obmarcesco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-marcesco</orth>, <itype>3</itype>, <sense id="n31727.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. inch. n., to fall away, grow lean</hi>: obmarcescebat febris, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 2, 30</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obmentans: <entryFree id="n31728" type="main" key="obmentans"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obmentans</orth>, v. ommento.</entryFree>
obmeritus: <entryFree id="n31729" type="gloss" key="obme^ri^tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-mĕrĭtus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> [ob-mereor], <sense id="n31729.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">having deserved well of</hi>, Rénier, Inscr. Afr. 444 al.: <cit><quote lang="la">parentes optime obmeritae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 966</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obmolior: <entryFree id="n31730" type="main" key="obmo_li^or"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-mōlĭor</orth>, <itype>ītus, 4</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos> (perh. not ante-Aug.). <sense id="n31730.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to push</hi> or <hi rend="ital">throw up</hi> one thing <hi rend="ital">before</hi> another (as a defence or obstruction): <cit><quote lang="la">nec in promptu erat quod obmolirentur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:33:5:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 33, 5, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">arborum truncos et saxa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:6:6:24" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 6, 6, 24</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31730.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to block up, obstruct</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad munienda et obmolienda, quae ruinis strata erant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:32:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 37, 32, 7</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:33:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 33, 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obmordeo: <entryFree id="n31731" type="main" key="obmorde^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-mordĕo</orth>, <itype>ēre</itype>, <sense id="n31731.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. a., to bite around</hi> (late Lat.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 20, 16, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obmoveo: <entryFree id="n31732" type="main" key="obmo^ve^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-mŏvĕo</orth>, <itype>2</itype>, <sense id="n31732.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. a., to move</hi> or <hi rend="ital">bring forward, produce, offer</hi> (ante-class.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 141, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Juppiter te hoc ferto obmovendo bonas preces precor (a form of prayer),</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 134, 2</bibl></cit>.—Cf.: obmoveto pro admoveto dicebatur apud antiquos, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=202" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 202</bibl> Müll.; and cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:37:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 9, 37, 2</bibl> Drak.</sense></entryFree>
obmurmuratio: <entryFree id="n31733" type="main" key="obmurmu^ra_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obmurmŭrātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>obmurmuro</etym>, <sense id="n31733.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a murmuring against; a murmuring</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">gravis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 26, 2, 3</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obmurmuro: <entryFree id="n31734" type="main" key="obmurmu^ro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-murmŭro</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <sense id="n31734.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. n., to murmur against, at</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">to</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg> and in post-Aug. prose); constr. with <case>dat.</case> or <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">precibusque meis obmurmurat ipse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:18:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 18, 47</bibl></cit>: itidem obmurmurasse: <foreign lang="greek">*ti/ ga/r moi</foreign>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=otho:7" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Oth. 7</bibl>: Pharisaei, quod, etc., <cb n="OBNO" /> Ambros. Cain et Abel, 2, 4, 16: obmurmurando dicere (with <hi rend="ital">object-clause</hi>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:4:6:2" default="NO"><author>Front.</author> 4, 6, 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obmussito: <entryFree id="n31735" type="main" key="obmussi^to"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obmussĭto</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. freq. a.</pos> <etym>obmusso</etym>, <sense id="n31735.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to whisper</hi> or <hi rend="ital">mutter against</hi> any one; <hi rend="ital">to mutter</hi> (eccl. Lat.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Pall. 4</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obmusso: <entryFree id="n31736" type="main" key="obmusso"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obmusso</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <sense id="n31736.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. a., to whisper against</hi> any one; <hi rend="ital">to whisper, mutter</hi> (eccl. Lat.). <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Anim. 18</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obmutesco: <entryFree id="n31737" type="main" key="obmu_tesco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-mūtesco</orth>, <itype>tŭi, 3</itype>, <sense id="n31737.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. inch. n., to become dumb, to lose one's speech</hi> (syn.: taceo, sileo). </sense><sense id="n31737.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui ebrius obmutuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 2, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum obmutuerint,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:127" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 27, 12, 104, § 127</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">umbrae ejus (hyaenae) contactu canes obmutescere,</quote> <trans><tr>lose their voice, their bark</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:106" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 8, 30, 44, § 106</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:40" default="NO" valid="yes">20, 5, 20, § 40</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31737.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, in gen., <hi rend="ital">to be speechless, mute, silent</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ipse obmutescam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:7:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 7, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">de me ... nulla umquam obmutescat vetustas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:35:98" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 35, 98</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aeneas aspectu obmutuit amens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:279" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 279</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dixit pressoque obmutuit ore,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 155</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obmutuit illa dolore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:538" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 538</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31737.3" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to become silent, to cease</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">studium nostrum conticuit subito et obmutuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:94:324" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 94, 324</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animi dolor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:21:50" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 2, 21, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Lydium sil nunc obmutuit,</quote> <trans><tr>is no longer asked for</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:160" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33, 12, 56, § 160</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dixit mari, obmutesce,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,002:4:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Marc. 4, 39</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obnatus: <entryFree id="n31738" type="hapax" key="obna_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-nātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n31738.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj., growing on</hi> or <hi rend="ital">about</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">obnata ripis salicta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:19:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 23, 19, 11</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obnectere: <entryFree id="n31739" type="gloss" key="obnecte^re"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obnectĕre</orth>, <itype>obligare, maxime in nuptiis frequens est</itype>, Paul. ex Fest p. 190 Müll.</entryFree>
obnexus: <entryFree id="n31740" type="main" key="obnexus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obnexus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>obnecto</etym>, <sense id="n31740.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a connecting, connection</hi> (eccl. Lat.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Marc. 4, 37</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obniger: <entryFree id="n31741" type="hapax" key="obni^ger"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-nĭger</orth>, <itype>gra, grum</itype>, <sense id="n31741.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj., blackish</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">radices,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:253" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 20, 23, 94, § 253</bibl></cit> Sillig. (al. obliquis nigris).</sense></entryFree>
obnise: <entryFree id="n31742" type="main" key="obni_se_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obnīsē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. obnitor, <sense id="n31742.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">P. a. fin</hi>.</sense></entryFree>
obnisus: <entryFree id="n31743" type="main" key="obni_sus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obnīsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> and <pos>P. a.</pos>, from obnitor.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n31744" type="greek" key="obni_sus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obnīsus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>obnitor</etym>, <sense id="n31744.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">exertion, trouble</hi>: Damascum capit obnisu levi, Auct. Itin. Alex. 41 Mai.</sense></entryFree>
obnitor: <entryFree id="n31745" type="main" key="obni_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-nītor</orth>, <itype>xus</itype> (rarely nīsus), 3 (<sense id="n31745.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">inf.</hi> obnitier for obniti, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:437" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 437</bibl>), <hi rend="ital">v. dep., to bear, press, push, struggle</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">strive against</hi> any thing (mostly <usg type="style">poet.</usg> and in post-Aug. prose; not in Cic. or Cæs.); constr. with the <hi rend="ital">dat., acc.</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> </sense><sense id="n31745.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">taurus Arboris obnixus trunco,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:105" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 105</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">contra,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">toto corpore obnitendum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:13:11" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 5, 13, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">remi Obnixi crepuere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:205" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 205</bibl></cit>: densis ales (Lachm. aquila hinc) pinnis obnixa volabat Vento, Enn. ap. Prob. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:6:31, p. 354" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 6, 31, p. 354</bibl> Lion. (Ann. v. 148 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">obnixi (al. obnisi) urgebant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 34, 46</bibl></cit>.—In <hi rend="ital">pass.</hi> signif.: obnixo genu scuto, <hi rend="ital">set</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pressed against</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Chabr. 1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Chabr. 1, 2</bibl>.— <cit><quote lang="la">Of things: navigia fractas obnitier undas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:437" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 437</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31745.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> </sense><sense id="n31745.3" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To strive against, to resist, oppose</hi> (class. only in <mood>Part.</mood>): <cit><quote lang="la">stant obnisi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:33:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 7, 33, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum saepe obnitens repugnasset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:89:5" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 89, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:123:2" default="NO">2, 123, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">stant obnixa omnia contra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:359" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 359</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">venti obnixi lacerant nubila,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:5:366" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 5, 366</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 11</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n31745.4" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To strive, endeavor;</hi> with <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">triumphum Pauli impedire obnitebantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:1:9:6" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 1, 9, 6</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">obnixus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">obnīsus</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">P. a., steadfast, firm, resolute</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">(velim) obnixos vos stabili gradu impetum hostium excipere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">firmitas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:105" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 15, 24, § 105</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obnixus curam sub corde premebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:332" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 332</bibl></cit>.—In <hi rend="ital">neutr.</hi>, adverb., <hi rend="ital">resolutely, obstinately</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">obnixum. Pauline, taces,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Ep. 25, 28</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">obnixē</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">obnīsē</orth>), lit., striving against; hence, in gen., <hi rend="ital">with all one's strength, with might and main, strenuously, obstinately</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">obnixe omnia Facere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:1:134" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 1, 134</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oboedire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:26:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 26, 12</bibl></cit> (dub.; <cit><quote lang="la">Weissenb. enixe): petere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 95:1" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 95, 1</bibl></cit> (Haase, enixe; v. Krebs, Antibarb. p. 781). —<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">argumentari,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud. Mam.</author> Stat. Anim. 1, 3</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obnixe: <entryFree id="n31746" type="main" key="obnixe_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obnixē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. obnitor, <sense id="n31746.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">P. a. fin</hi>.</sense></entryFree>
obnixus: <entryFree id="n31747" type="main" key="obnixus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obnixus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> and <pos>P. a.</pos>, from obnitor.</entryFree>
obnoxie: <entryFree id="n31748" type="main" key="obnoxi^e_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obnoxĭē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. obnoxius <sense id="n31748.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
obnoxio: <entryFree id="n31749" type="main" key="obnoxi^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obnoxĭo</orth>, <itype>1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>obnoxius</etym>, <sense id="n31749.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to render subject</hi> or <hi rend="ital">obnoxious to</hi> any thing (postclass.): <cit><quote lang="la">et alienis semet noxiis obnoxiantes,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud. Mam.</author> Stat. Anim. 2, 9</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obnoxiose: <entryFree id="n31750" type="main" key="obnoxi^o_se_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obnoxĭōsē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. obnoxiosus <sense id="n31750.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
obnoxiosus: <entryFree id="n31751" type="main" key="obnoxi^o_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obnoxĭōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>obnoxius</etym> <cb n="OBNU" /> (ante-class.). <sense id="n31751.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subject, submissive, obedient</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">alicui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:4:3:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 4, 3, 31</bibl></cit>.—* </sense><sense id="n31751.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Hurtful, injurious, dangerous</hi>: res, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:7:17:10" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 7, 17, 10</bibl> (Trag. v. 341 Vahl.).—Hence, <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">obnoxĭōsē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">abjectly, timidly.— Comp.</hi>, obnoxiosius, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:5:2:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 5, 2, 30</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obnoxius: <entryFree id="n31752" type="main" key="obnoxi^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-noxĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <sense id="n31752.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n31752.1" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Subject, liable to punishment, obnoxious to punishment, punishable</hi>: obnoxius poenae obligatus ob delictum, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=191" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 191</bibl> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">ego tibi me obnoxium esse fateor culpae compotem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:4:3:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 4, 3, 61</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:48:15:1" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 48, 15, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ego lege Aquiliā obnoxius sum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:11:3:14" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 11, 3, 14</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31752.2" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Liable</hi> or <hi rend="ital">addicted to</hi> a fault or failing, <hi rend="ital">guilty of</hi> it (cf.: deditus, addictus); constr. </sense><sense id="n31752.3" n="1" level="3"> With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">animus neque delicto neque lubidini obnoxius,</quote> <trans><tr>not addicted to vice or to sensual pleasures</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 52:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 52, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">communi culpae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:1:395" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 1, 395</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">facto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:3:4:15" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 3, 4, 15</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31752.4" n="2" level="3"> With <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">obnoxios criminum, digno supplicio subjectos, sepulturae tradi non vetamus,</quote> <trans><tr>for, on account of</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cod. Just.</author> 3, 44, 11</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31752.5" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, in gen. </sense><sense id="n31752.6" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Subject, submissive, obedient, complying</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">dum illos obnoxios fidosque sibi faceret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 14:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 14, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obnoxium atque subjectum esse alicui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:30:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 7, 30, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:28:7" default="NO" valid="yes">6, 28, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:12:9" default="NO" valid="yes">23, 12, 9</bibl>; 37, 53, 4; 42, 46, 3; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:4:4:2" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 4, 4, 2</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n31752.7" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Obliged, under obligation, beholden, indebted, responsible, answerable</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">uxori obnoxius sum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:3:1:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 3, 1, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">totam Graeciam beneficio libertatis obnoxiam Romanis esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:35:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 35, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fratris radiis obnoxia Luna,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:396" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 396</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">facies nullis obnoxia gemmis,</quote> <trans><tr>not indebted to any jewels</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:1:2:21" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 1, 2, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tantum in eo obnoxius est, si quid ipse dolo fecerit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1251,001:Inst. 3:207" default="NO"><author>Gai.</author> Inst. 3, 207</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31752.8" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Exposed to a person, humbled before</hi> one: <cit><quote lang="la">ne obnoxius filio sim et servo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:5:2:80" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 5, 2, 80</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31752.9" n="D" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Submissive, abject, servile, slavish, mean-spirited, timid, cowardly</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">non quibus ego essem obnoxius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:1:150" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 3, 1, 150</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">summissaeque manus, faciesque obnoxia mansit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:5:235" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 5, 235</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si aut superbus, aut obnoxius videar,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 23, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pax,</quote> <trans><tr>servile, dishonorable</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 9, 10</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31752.10" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Subject, liable, exposed, obnoxious</hi> to any thing; with <hi rend="ital">dat., ad</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">in</hi> and <case>acc.</case> </sense><sense id="n31752.11" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">infidis consiliis obnoxius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">insidiis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:14:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 14, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">infelici fecunditate fortunae,</quote> <trans><tr>exposed</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 75</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aemulationi, odio, privatis affectionibus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 58</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">morbo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:221" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 24, 37, § 221</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">contumeliis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:63" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 63</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bello,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:1:8:73" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 1, 8, 73</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plerique Crasso ex negotiis privatis obnoxii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 48:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 48, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">urbs artis itineribus (sc. incendiis),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 38</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31752.12" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>: terra solida ad tales casus obnoxia, <hi rend="ital">exposed to such accidents</hi> (viz. earthquakes), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:197" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 82, 84, § 197</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31752.13" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">in</hi> and <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in omnia obnoxius,</quote> <trans><tr>exposed to every thing</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:3:20:1" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 3, 20, 1</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n31752.14" n="3" level="3"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">exposed</hi> or <hi rend="ital">liable to injury, danger</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">misfortune, weak, infirm, frail</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in hoc obnoxio domicilio animus liber habitat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 65:21" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 65, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">supplex et obnoxius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,059:1:17:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> ad Brut. 1, 17, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">corpora,</quote> <trans><tr>sickly, weakly</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:31:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 31, 6, 32, § 60</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">flos,</quote> <trans><tr>which soon falls off, soon suffers injury, frail, delicate</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 14, 2, 4, § 27</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31752.15" n="b" level="4"> Obnoxium est, <hi rend="ital">it is hazardous, dangerous</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tac.</author> Or. 10</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">obnoxior (al. noxior),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Clem. 1:13" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Clem. 1, 13</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">obnoxĭē</orth> (only in Plaut. and Liv.). </sense><sense id="n31752.16" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Guiltily, culpably</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil obnoxie perire,</quote> <trans><tr>quite innocently</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:3:2:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 3, 2, 41</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n31752.17" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Submissively, slavishly, timidly</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sententias dicere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:39:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 39, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
